High-skilled migrants are moving from diverse countries to a select few, notably the US, UK, Canada, and Australia. In 2010, these 4 countries attracted nearly 70% of high-skilled migrants to the OECD.

U.S. real total capex reached an all-time high in Q1 2021, driven by hard & intangible capex. Core capital goods orders have shown consistent growth, with nondefense orders increasing in 13 of the last 15 months.
Gold fell by as much as 6.3% (5.2% as of now) today after hitting a record high on Monday. Year-to-date, gold has risen 55%.

Gold accounted for 20% of global official reserves in 2024, outstripping the euro’s 16%, and second only to the US dollar at 46%. The price has risen 27% this year to an historic nominal high of $3,500/troy ounce.

Gold prices hit a record high of $3,508.70/troy ounce; prices have doubled since the beginning of 2023. Last year, gold became the world’s second-most common central bank reserve asset after the dollar.

Gold’s spot price has risen 50% since the start of the year. Since Powell’s Jackson speech, gold has risen 18% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.

Gold has surpassed its real peak in 1980, hitting an all-time, inflation-adjusted high of $3,674.27 per Troy ounce. When gold hit $850 nominal in January 1980 (~ $3,590 in 2025 dollars), the US was grappling with a collapsing currency and stagflation.
The age of peak earnings, or "golden age," has remained stable at 45-50 years old in the U.S. over the past 30 years, but decreased from 55 to 33 years old in China.

Since January, gold is up 42.4%, experiencing its strongest rally since 1979. John Authers argues the rally “seems to be driven by rational calculations of central banks,” suggesting it’s sustainable.

The value of foreign central banks' gold holdings, currently $3.83T, will likely soon eclipse the value of their Treasury holdings, now $3.92. Gold has already overtaken the euro as central banks’ second-largest asset.

11/20 sub-categories of core goods have likely reacted to tariffs, with an overall impact of 50% pass-through to consumption goods. Virtually all tariff increases for household appliances have been passed on whereas the prices of new cars have not risen.
Engineering teams at IBM and Google both believe they are on track to build industrial-scale quantum computers by the end of the decade.
Google claims it successfully ran an algorithm on “Willow,” its quantum computing chip. The breakthrough “clears a path for useful applications of quantum technology within five years.”
Low interest rates are not mysterious but result from higher savings, lower growth, and increased market power, according to @GregMankiw.

Gust and Skaperdas find that when people form expectations of future debt over a cognitively realistic 5 yr horizon, a permanent 1 ppt increase in debt-to-GDP raises the term premium on the 10-year by only 3 bps, half of the perfect foresight estimate.

U.S. patents relying on federal funding plateaued at 30% in 2011 and is currently around 28%. The absolute number of patents dependent on federally supported research nearly doubled from 22,647 in 2008 to 45,220 in 2017.
According to @WilliamRKerr @nberpubs 55% of productivity growth stems from expansion into new niches, while 20% comes from shop floor improvements & 20% from new firm creation.
Research by @RichardTownsend finds CEO pay has increased due to firms granting consistent stock options, whose value has risen with firm equity returns, averaging 30% annually during the Tech Boom.

Approaching the Trump administration’s self-imposed 90-day deadline for trade deals, Torsten Sløk posits that extending the deadline by one year would leave trade partners "happy" with 10% and Trump with $400B of annual revenue.

According to an FT analysis, time spent on social media globally has declined 10% since its 2022 peak. An exception is North America, where in 2024 users spent 15% more time on social media than Europeans.

Over the past 10 years, $9T has been spent globally on electrification, however Michael Cembalest points out that renewables' share of final energy consumption is still advancing at only 0.3-0.6% per year.

Tariffs implemented during the 2018-2019 trade war were “at best a wash, and may have been mildly negative” in terms of employment, but increased political support for Trump in the 2020 election. @davidautor
Research on Danish manufacturing firms reveals that offshoring to low-wage countries leads to significant shifts in domestic employment composition, with a rise in tech and research-related roles.

The share of US firms with growth over 130%/year declined from 18% in 1985 to 12% in 2015, driven by a decline in new firm formation and slower growth among existing firms. @ngoldschlag @JHaltiwanger_UM @jdanielkim
Btw 2014-2016, the top 100 high-income nonfilers failed to pay nearly $10bn in taxes, highlighting a significant oversight by the IRS.
US health care spending rose 5.8% to $3.2tn in 2015, driven by the Affordable Care Act's coverage expansion. Spending per person was $9,990. @CMSGov.

Btw 2019 and 2023, automation helped China increase its export share in labor-intensive sectors. During that period, Chinese manufacturers added ~280,000 industrial robots every year, 50% of the global total.

Given subsequent price appreciation and the “stability of homeownership post-1960,” purchasing a home btw 1940 and 1960 was an entree into the middle class that renters in the bottom income-tercile in 1955 largely missed out on.
Paul Kedrosky estimates that AI capex drove 20 to 40% of US GDP growth of 3% per annum in Q2, noting "for practical purposes (AI capex) ate Q2 GDP growth."
Relative to median household income, home prices are 3% under the bubble peak and ~9% below the recent peak. Measures of home prices relative to income remain elevated.
US households showed limited balance sheet adjustments after the Great Recession, with debt reduction due to less new borrowing rather than increased repayment.
UK data shows changes in debt-to-income ratios had a bigger impact on household consumption than absolute debt levels, rejecting the debt-overhang hypothesis.
Median annual household income reached $63,378 in February 2019, a 1.9% increase Y/Y from February 2018, according to @SentierResearch.

US data since 1919 shows that volatility in building permits foreshadows financial market volatility. “Cities and states with more elastic housing supply consistently predict financial market downturns at 12-month horizons.” @cslapoint @CortesGustavoS
Superstar cities see faster house price growth but lower total returns due to higher rental returns in more remote locations. National superstars trail national averages by 90-100 basis points.

Brooks expresses alarm at the “unprecedented” sharp rise in market-implied Japanese and European forward yields at the long end, “as the debt crisis in the Eurozone still festers.” The “less worrying” picture for the US is likely a safe haven effect.

As AI-related investment has risen since 2023, residential and nonresidential investment have declined or flatlined. This may suggest that a relatively rate-insensitive AI buildout is crowding out more interest-sensitive forms of investment.

Over the past 50 years, federal spending has averaged 21.1% of GDP, rising to 24.4% post-pandemic. Revenues, at 18.3% of GDP, remain above the 17.3% 50-year average, but not enough to cover interest costs and “relentlessly” rising Medicare and Medicaid.

In 2024, BYD sold 4.27mm cars, a 10-fold increase in four years; 1.76mm were pure EVs, almost on par with Tesla’s 1.79mm. Over those four years, Tesla’s production rose only 3.6x. Both firms are focusing on autonomous driving.

As measured by tonnage, China built 57% of ships globally in 2024 and has 59% of outstanding orders going forward. While it lags in production of the most complex ships, it still has ⅓ of the LNG orderbook.
Enormous government subsidies for EVs are reducing Chinese oil demand, which is expected to peak in 2027.
An Australian analysis of the top 10% of high-quality scientific publications found Chinese researchers have surpassed American researchers across 8 critical technology domains.

The cost per watt of the newest nuclear plants in the US is $15, relative to $1.67-$2.58 per watt for Chinese nuclear plants under construction. Since 2013, the US has built two new nuclear reactors while China has built 13 and has 33 underway.

China is undertaking a large-scale infrastructure build on its eastern coast, including new naval bases for amphibious vessels with hardened fuel tanks. Michael Dahm, a retired U.S. Navy intelligence officer, argues “they expect this to be bombed.”

The US prime-age employment-to-population ratio and the job-finding rate for those in the labor force are ~at the European mean. But the US participation rate has fallen below 90%, on par with Italy at the bottom of the pack, driven by men ages 25–34.

Robin Brooks argues the “unprecedented” immigration wave under Biden “collided with a segmented labor market that was leaving more and more people on the sidelines.” He implies the marginal native male worker is worse off due to increased competition.

A year after a Chinese “5 Year Plan,” employment, investment, and output of US establishments in industries designated by China for increased subsidies begin to drop significantly, followed by plant closures.

An experiment using repeated random assignments of managers finds that good managers have twice the impact on team performance as good workers. Randomly assigned managers do better than self-nominated ones. @ProfDavidDeming @SoniaBhalotra @_farahsaid
“Much of the $40 billion of chips the US imports are actually made in the US, packaged abroad, and reimported,” Chris Miller argues. Thus “tariffs would senselessly penalize domestic manufacturers.”

.@Brad_Setser @SanderTordoir note that the EU has 30mm manufacturing workers, 2x what the US had before the 1st China Shock, and argue that for the EU a 2nd China Shock “will be associated with the loss of export markets, not just a surge in imports.”

In 2015, federal and state educational spending revealed a $1,013 per-student disparity favoring poor students, totaling $10.4bn. Despite targeted funding of $67.8bn for poor students, the larger non-poor demographic led to $219.9bn more spending on them.

Treasury market liquidity, whether measured by bid-ask spreads, order book depth, or Treasury price volatility, sharply declined in response to the April 2 tariff announcement, but quickly recovered after April 9, when the tariffs were mostly postponed.

Over 2019–2024, 2nd-generation immigrant black female workers had earnings as high, or higher, than (non-hispanic) white women; 2nd-generation black male workers earned 10% < these white workers at the median, but this gap disappears at the top decile.
The federal financial safety net has expanded significantly, covering $25tn in financial assets, a substantial portion of the U.S. financial system.
Airbus is now at par with Boeing as measured by cumulative deliveries, though the A320 launched 20 years after the 737. Boeing still leads in larger wide-body aircraft.
"There are still more criminals than you might expect." 6.2% of white American men, 14.4% of hispanic men, and 26% of black men born in 1991 will have been imprisoned by the time they turn 50.

Biden’s benefits package could provide a family of four with two unemployed adults an after-tax income exceeding $135,000 in Kansas and $170,000 in Massachusetts, surpassing 85% of household wages. This may reduce employment by 5-7m, or over 8m if the $15 minimum wage is included.
California now has 13GW of battery storage capacity and plans to add another 8.6GW by 2027; the batteries consistently supplied 25% of the state’s electricity during the spring and summer peaks.

When applying U.S. income standards to Western Europe, the middle-class share shrinks significantly, highlighting disparities in living standards. In 2010, U.S. middle-class incomes ranged from $35,294 to $105,881, adjusted for cost-of-living differences.
Education boosts intelligence by 1-5 IQ points per year, according to a meta-analysis of 142 effect sizes from 42 data sets involving over 600,000 participants.

Until the TCJA, the top 400 US individuals by wealth and the full US population both had effective tax rates of ~30%. The TCJA reduced the Top 400 individuals’ total ETRs to 23.8% in 2018 - 2020, well below those of the full population.

A correction on the scale of the dotcom crash, when the S&P 500's value relative to the size of the economy fell by 53pp, would reduce household wealth by 8% and have a larger impact on the economy today due to households' increased exposure to stocks.

.@swinshi notes that @JacobBastian25’s latest research underestimates the disemployment effects of an enhanced Child Tax Credit. Scott view of the disemployment effects support Bruce Myers and @kefincorinth CTC estimates @UChicago. @aei

Kevin Corinth finds that childless, non-disabled, non-working adult Medicaid recipients aged 19–64 spend 14.4 hours a day sleeping and watching tv/video games, 3 hours more per day than their working peers.

Given that deflation is becoming entrenched in China, Robin Brooks argues that the US has the upper hand in the trade war. He cautions that easing up on China's exporters while China's hold on rare earths is undiminished, undermines the US position going forward.

As of July 2025, ChatGPT was used at least weekly by ~10% of the global adult population. 70% of usage was non-work related. Work usage was most common for educated users in high-pay professional occupations.

While the dollar’s weakness is likely being driven by the same fiscal deterioration that is spiking long yields in Germany and Japan, the imposition of tariffs had a real impact on the US's convenience yield relative to other safe havens.

Between 2000 and 2018, high-income cities had greater income growth, raising the relative demand for housing in them. Because these cities also face more geographic and regulatory obstacles to new housing, house prices and rents rose in the aggregate.
Sweden's market reforms: Govt spend cut 70% to <50% GDP, debt 80% to 41%, corp tax -6pts to 22%. Results: Growth +1pt vs EU since 1995, GDP/capita now at 85% of US. Ranks 15th in economic freedom.
Barclays estimates that AI-related investment constituted half of America’s 1.6% annualized GDP growth in the first half of 2025.

U.S. labor market remains historically tight, with a significant employment shortfall persisting through 2022. Key factors include Covid-19 health concerns, immigration restrictions, excess retirements, demographic shifts, and reduced incentives to work.

To counter Chinese style “persistent, policy-engineered surpluses—designed, e.g., to boost a country’s manufacturing share by suppressing wage growth,” Pettis proposes a “global customs union open to all countries that commit to balanced trade.”

As inheritances in the rich world rise to gilded age levels, Victor Haghani and James White calculate that an optimal mix of stocks and bonds since 1900 would have yielded 10% per year, exceeding the 6.6% from an all-stock strategy, with less volatility.

Substrate, a US startup, has invented a new X-ray lithography tool; if its performance claims are borne out, “leading edge wafers [could be] produced at 50% less than existing options,” disrupting both ASML’s and TSMC’s effective monopolies.

.@paulkrugman argues “if we believe our numbers, which maybe we shouldn't, but if we believe our numbers, total factor productivity growth has been really pretty lousy" for the last 20 years, even with significant technological changes.

The IMF argues that a well-designed tax on income from capital, at a lower rate than labor income, would be less distortive and more equitable than a wealth tax if countries seek to raise more revenue from the rich.

Japan's non-Japanese population has surged to 3.5mm, 3% of the population. By 2026, there will be 1mm Chinese nationals living full-time in Japan, largely middle-class Chinese - a phenomenon referred to as Run-ri.

Robin Brooks argues China's record good surplus overstates the strength of its export sector. Brooks suggests that the effect of tariffs has been to suppress Chinese margins, as exporters cut prices to sell to the non-US market.

Treasuries must be an asset that “can be quickly liquidated for cash” in a crisis. Treasury markets are “growing too large to rely exclusively on dealers to intermediate” these trades, and require central clearing and “all-to-all” trading, Duffie argues.
10-year gilt yields are the highest across the G7. Goldman estimates the UK needs a fiscal consolidation of ~ 3% of GDP to attain a primary balance of ~1% to stabilize debt.
A progressive wealth tax could target the top 0.1% of wealth holders, who own 20% of US wealth. A 2% tax on wealth btw $50m & $1bn, and 3% on wealth above $1bn, could generate $2.75tn over a decade.

Federal savings from extending Medicare coverage to include weight loss drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy won’t remotely offset the cost, which @USCO forecasts at $35B between 2026-2034. Over ⅔ of current Medicare beneficiaries are overweight or obese.

A New York Times analysis of the NYC democratic primary electorate found a significant shift in voters’ age profile. While < 50,000 people 18–24 voted in 2021, the participation of that cohort tripled this year.
Research indicates running a "high pressure" economy can mitigate hysteresis effects by encouraging higher labor force participation & investment. @ValerieCerra

Brad DeLong suggests that AI investment is largely defensive in nature, “with fear of AI‑driven disruption defining the moment,” and is skeptical regarding its prospects. ”What, concretely, are the ‘new-and-improved’ services that justify the AI boom?”
IBM Quantum Starling aims to achieve 20,000x the compute of current quantum computers by 2029, leveraging advanced error-correction techniques to ensure fault tolerance.
An analysis of recent CPS data by the Center for Immigration Studies suggests that there were 14.8mm illegal immigrants in the US in May 2025, 1mm fewer than the Center’s January estimate.
@KirstenFleming US Trust study: 77% of wealthy respondents said they grew up poor or middle class, Fidelity study: 86% of wealth is self-made.
IMF data shows a significant decline in the cost of capital goods, with shares and relative prices of investment categories shifting in response.
Immigrants have started more than half of the nation's $1bn+ startup companies, creating 760 jobs on average per company & holding a value of $168bn, nearly half Russia's stock market value.
Immigrants in Norway, Sweden, and Denmark face significant integration challenges, with lower labor force participation rates compared to natives. In Norway, immigrant LFP is 61%, vs 76% for natives.

Revised projections of net migration for 2025 span a range from −525,000 to 115,000, “reflecting [an] expectation of severely curtailed inflows” and only “somewhat” higher outflows, strongly weighted towards large negative net flows. @stanveuger @AEIecon
Median household increased 6.8% in 2019 hitting $68,703, poverty rate hit’s record low.

In the SCF, the wealth share of the top 0.1% of the wealth distribution rose from 10.6% in 1989 to 14.7% in 2022. Adding the Forbes 400 to the sample yields an increase from 12.2% to 17.1%. The Forbes 400 share rose from 1.8% to 2.8%.

Mogstad et al find that over 70% of the difference in earnings variability between the Nordic countries and the US/UK is due to a lower skill premium rather than skill variability, likely the result of wage compression due to collective bargaining.

Urban income study: Downtown housing costs driven by top earner influx; welfare gap btw 90th/10th percentiles widened 18% points (1990-2013). Higher-income residents' spatial preferences amplify inequality
Real median household income was $83,730 in 2024, effectively flat from 2019's $83,260.

New @KurtMitman study on Missouri's 2011 UI duration cut reveals a 11.1% increase in job finding rates, driven by heightened search efforts & labor market tightness. The elasticity of job finding rates with respect to UI durations was -0.45.

Jonathan Sine argues China’s global manufacturing share is likely near its peak as growth has slowed from 1.5% to 0.5% btw 2010 and today due to deglobalization and intensified countermeasures against Chinese industrial policy.

Chris Miller asks, "How much inefficiency should we swallow in exchange for the security of self-sufficiency?" He argues it's "a tricky calculation" as "security gains are probabilistic" and "long-term economic costs are highly speculative."

Chetty's mobility data, when scrutinized for uncertainty, reveals significant limitations in its robustness. While conclusions about academic achievement across countries remain stable, findings on intergenerational mobility in the U.S. are less reliable.

Nationally, real house prices are now 2% below the 2022 peak and 10.5% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%. @calculatedrisk

Nationally, real house prices are now 2.5% below the 2022 peak and 10% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%. @calculatedrisk
Nationally, real house prices are now 2.7% below the 2022 peak and 9.8% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%.
Nationally, real house prices are now 2.8% below the 2022 peak and 9.6% above the 2006 peak. “Affordability” remains at levels last seen in the early 1980s, when 30-year mortgage rates were over 14%.
Evidence from German investors finds that educating investors about negative stock market returns during inflation causes them to reduce their return expectations and purchases of equities.

Since 2019, American households have accumulated $59T in net wealth. Overall household net worth could finance 8.5 years of current spending. “Lowering interest rates would be…particularly risky given the financial position of American consumers.”

Wage growth for the typical US worker has been steady at 1–1.5pp above the pre-pandemic level, paralleling inflation. Matt Klein argues Trump’s desired 300bp drop in the FFR to lower the costs of debt service would be "extraordinarily inflationary."

In a trial with 50 physicians to test the impact of GPT-4 on diagnostic accuracy, the median diagnostic reasoning score was 76% for the GPT-4 group and 74% for the conventional resources group. GPT-4 alone scored 89%
IT, not anticompetitive measures, is driving industry consolidation. Top firms benefit from enhanced performance metrics, contributing to a widening productivity gap btw leading firms and others.
The cost of building one mile of interstate highway in 1980 was 3x the cost in 1960, adjusted for inflation. @LeahBrooks, Brookings Institution.

Europe allocates 53% of its R&D to the automotive sector, yet its global share of superstar firms has halved since 1999. Europe's private R&D investment is only 19% of the global total, trailing behind China & the US.

At ~3:1, the ratio of nonfinancial assets to liabilities is at its highest level since 1985. Since Covid, Americans in the bottom 60% have seen an ~43% rise in the value of durable goods owned relative to consumer credit owed, the highest across cohorts.
According to Bank of America internal data, median annual property insurance (auto and housing) payments have risen from 4% of household income to 5% over the past four years.
Intangible capital plays a significant role in economic growth for both the EU and US, with data showing intangibles account for 20-25% of market sector labor productivity growth in Europe.

The 10-yr TIPS break-even, at 2.3%, is only 20 bps above its 20-year mean of 2.1%: expected inflation is anchored, but the cyclically adjusted E/P ratio minus the 10-yr TIPS yield, a measure of the equity premium, is at worryingly low June 2007 levels.
American mobility is generally lower than in Canada, primarily due to low mobility levels in the American South. Excluding the South, US mobility aligns more closely with Canadian levels.

Research by @GuglielmoBarone @SauroMocetti shows that the same families in Florence have maintained wealth & status over 6 centuries, with earnings elasticity of 0.04 & strong real wealth inheritance. Published in @AIEL_Italia.
WWII R&D impact: Counties with 2x OSRD patents see +60-65% tech employment by 1970s. Wartime innovation clusters drive long-term regional economic specialization. @nberpub

The global stock of investable assets is valued at $261T, or ~ 200% of world GDP, up from ~75% in the 1990s. The weight of equity relative to bonds is higher than it was post-GFC, but below 1990s levels.
Patent data highlights key technological revolutions from 1842 to 2022, with railroads, steel, automobiles, and internet driving economic transformation.

A study of 51 large U.S. ports over 2010-2021 indicates that only 15 ports would deliver a positive return on infrastructure investment, driven in part by high congestion at the port and the potential to relieve congestion at other ports. @myrto_kaloup

“Jitters over Silicon Valley’s boom in spending on AI have spilled into the bond market.” According to BAC data, a basket of bonds issued by the major hyperscalers has seen an uptick in its spread over Treasuries to 0.78pp, up from 0.5pp in September.

New evidence from @SabrinaHowell shows US angel tax credits increase angel investments by 18% & individual angel investors by 27%, but don't impact professional investors' decisions, instead favoring low-growth firms.

The debt of several blue-chip firms, including Microsoft in the US, Siemens in Germany and LVHM in France, trades at lower yields than the underlying government benchmark, as “tough fiscal compromises” look unlikely.

“Educationally similar” monozygotic (MZ) twins raised apart [TRA] have a mean IQ delta of 5.8 points, ~ the same as those raised together. “Educationally dissimilar” MZ TRA have a delta of 12.8 points, closer to non-twin siblings than twins reared together.
Ireland's free college experiment has led to a decline in its universities' international rankings, highlighting potential pitfalls for similar policies elsewhere. @JasonDDelisle.

Azhar & Warren conclude that the AI buildout is a “demand-led, capital intensive boom,” not a bubble, given capex relative to GDP and revenue, revenue growth, and funding quality. If revenues grow at half their 2024 pace, they will reach $100B by 2026.
The rate of performance improvement of large language models may be slowing, as models face both data availability and compute constraints. GPT-5’s launch underwhelmed many in the sector.

Since ChatGPT launched, Adzuna data shows a 43% decline in US entry-level job postings requiring a degree. An FT analysis finds "no clear correlation" btw an occupation’s potential exposure to generative AI and a loss of young workers btw 2022–2024.
Among religious Americans aged 18–39, 57% and 66% of women and men, respectively, report wanting children someday, compared to 33% and 31% of their non-religious peers.

A commuting zone 125 miles farther from the closest pre-2007 AI hotspot has 17% lower growth in AI jobs’ share of vacancies over 7 years. A hotspot is defined as having 1,000 AI-related publications and patents related to “deep learning.”

Following tepid reactions to the release of GTP-5, Joe Wang observes, "It is looking more like companies are spending hundreds of billions on rapidly depreciating GPUs that produce a commoditized product that most clients only modestly benefit from."

Technological rivalry raises obsolescence risk, reducing the time over which adjustment costs can be recovered and thus reducing firm growth in response to innovation, reconciling an increase in the rate of innovation with a slowdown in aggregate TFP.

Analysis of firm and establishment-level data from Korea shows that software and labor are substitutes and that the rise of software accounts for two-thirds of the decline in Korean labor share of income between 1990 and 2018. @NBERpubs
American public corporations have seen significant volatility in equity value since 1999, with a notable shift towards fewer, larger, older, and less profitable firms.

US investment has been lower than predicted by fundamentals since 2000, driven by decreased competition & increased market concentration. Europe's investment aligns with profitability & Tobin's Q, except during crisis peaks.

Israeli officials credit the US Thaad missile defense systems for saving thousands of lives during their recent war with Iran. The US fired ~25% of its stock during the 12-day war. Each missile costs ~$13mm, DoD has budgeted to buy 37 over the next year.
School desegregation significantly reduced the test-score gap btw black and white children, cutting it in half for some black age groups without harming white children.

Italy’s population decline is among the most acute in Europe, per Istat, and ~191k people left the country in 2024, the highest level in 25 years. 50% of leavers in 2023 held a college degree, creating “a significant deficit of qualified human capital.”

An upcoming vote might provide an easier path to Italian citizenship for 5.4mm legal foreign residents, addressing the demographic challenge of a population where 25% is over 65. 13.5% of new births in Italy last year were to foreign parents.

BLS’s American Time Use Survey shows that 15 to 25-year-olds spend 26 fewer minutes a day socializing than they did in 2003. For the first time ever, adults 50 and older spent more time socializing in person than teens and young adults.

Since 2023, foreign investors have bought a net $1.2T of coupon Treasuries, or 1/3 of the net private coupon supply. The falling dollar and rising yields abroad will likely reduce foreign demand for Treasuries and “ultimately force lower fiscal spending.”
DEI impact assessment reveals key gaps: Mandatory training shows null/negative effects. Racial wage gap analysis: Black-white male earnings gap -39.4% narrows to -10.9% adjusted for education.
The CBO projected 3.3% real GDP growth for 2018, but actual growth was 2.9%, suggesting a smaller-than-anticipated effect of the tax revision.
Japanese long bond yields rose, with the 20- and 30-year hitting 2.6% and 3.2%, respectively. Globally, long yields are rising. The US 30-year Treasury is approaching a 5% yield.

Japan's new Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi has unveiled a plan to raise defense spending to 2% of GDP by this spring. If this goal is met, the plan would achieve Tokyo’s 2% defense spending target two years ahead of the current trajectory of March 2028.

Births in Japan fell to < 700,000 in 2024 for the first time since records began in the 19th century, 15 years ahead of the IPSS median forecast. Analysts are urging the government to use lower birth data for policy analysis.

Brooks argues BoJ intervention is still "massively" distorting Japan’s long-term yields, noting that Japan, with debt at 240% of GDP, and Germany, with debt at 65% of GDP, both have ~ the same 30-year government bond yield.
Yields on the 10-year JGB hit 1.78%, the highest level since June 2008, as investors anticipate further fiscal expansion in Japan.
The Japanese 30-year yield is still below Germany’s, despite Japan's debt/GDP of 240% relative to Germany’s 65%. The Bank of Japan is currently engaged in a yield control effort to manage rates.

In 2025H2, BoJ was a net seller of JGB’s to the tune of 2.6% of GDP, as maturing debt exceeded mean gross monthly purchases of ¥4.7T. A planned reduction in purchases to a mean of ¥2T “will likely send longer-term yields even higher.”

If Japan sticks with low interest rates, it faces a further drop in the yen and worsening inflation. Rising yields put Japan’s debt sustainability at risk. “This catch-22 means a debt crisis is much closer than people think,” Brooks argues.

Japan has so far avoided inflation and debt crises despite decades of slow growth and deficits that left gov debt at > twice GDP by “running a risky sovereign wealth fund” with maturity and currency mismatch, financed at below-market interest rates.

An ~18pp rise in female labor force participation between 2000 and 2025, an ~7pp rise in participation of seniors since 2012, and a 30-year low in youth unemployment have temporarily mitigated the decline in Japan’s labor force, which peaked in 1995.
Americans’ workforce earning <$29,000 a year is down 20% relative to January 2020 level; adjusted for workers earning more than $29K, workforce is down 13.5%.

Weak labor demand is not keeping pace with “modest” labor supply growth. Outside of the healthcare sector, job growth is now net negative. Mericle and Mei note that the impact of AI on the labor market may “not become apparent until a recession hits.”
Evidence supports "indebted demand" theory, showing income inequality exerts downward pressure on natural rates of interest (r*).

JPM estimates that since the start of the year, the Fed’s treasury holdings dropped $180B and commercial banks’ holdings have decreased by $60B. Foreign official holdings fell by $50B over the last 6 months on a rolling basis, according to the analysis.
Michael Cembalest notes the 10-year Treasury has been rising in a cutting cycle as the market anticipates the Fed’s response to a "tariff/deportation/loose fiscal agenda."
VC investments in start-ups within the same sector drop by 40% after acquisitions by Google or Facebook, highlighting unique economic dynamics of digital platforms.

Analysis of >5k German fighter pilots reveals that awards & status competition significantly influenced performance, with disparities across skill levels. Skilled pilots increased victory scores without higher mortality rates, while average pilots showed minimal improvement in victories & higher mortality.

Nicholas Eberstadt argues China’s “knowledge capital” as measured by PISA test scores, may be overstated, as testing is limited to four high income provinces/municipalities, excluding 85% of the population.

US welfare expansion reaches historic scale: Government support for low-income families rising to $76.4k/yr (+$11.2k), total resources to $94.6k. Impact: 26.3m children (33% of US), 12.5m families at 100-200% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL).

IHME models for predicting COVID19 daily deaths have significant discrepancies. True number of next day deaths fell outside IHME prediction intervals up to 70% of the time, far exceeding the expected 5%. @OriRosen
Research by @T_Robert_Fetter finds that fracking firms' productivity increased after regulation forced disclosure of trade secrets, as lagging firms caught up with market leaders.

Younger individuals, having lived through recent high inflation periods, tend to forecast higher future inflation compared to older individuals who draw on a broader historical context. @UlrikeMalmendier

Btw 2010 and 2023, enrollment at US colleges declined from 17.3mm to 14.1mm. 90% of the decline was driven by falling enrollment in the bottom two quintiles of schools. The top two quintile schools gained enrollment by 3% and 8%, respectively.

Leisure technologies, such as the internet & TV, have contributed to a decline in TFP growth by altering time allocation patterns. Average hours worked have decreased by -0.5% annual growth rate across advanced economies, while leisure hours have increased.
Danish and American intergenerational educational mobility ~ mirror each other despite Denmark’s social spending.

.@gchodorowreich @omzidar and Eric Zwich conclude that the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act raised tangible corporate investment by about 11%, but long-run GDP by less than 1% while reducing corporate tax revenue by 40%.
Jason Thomas argues that high rates driven by the AI buildout and US fiscal policy are “crowding out interest-sensitive sectors like for-sale housing.”

Public firms have easier access to capital during stress periods like the Great Recession, unlike private firms whose leverage declines, according to @EminDinlersoz @SebnemKalemliOzcan @HenryHyatt @VeronikaPenciakova @nberpubsorg.

Paul Kedrosky argues the American economy is undergoing a fundamental shift from > 3% mean annual real GDP growth to "life under two," or below 2% annually. If maintained, this shift from "abundance" to "scarcity" will change American life.

Jonathon Sine argues China “is moving beyond its breakneck industrial prime, facing similar dilemmas to those America confronted in the 1960s and 70s.” The ratio of science/engineering to humanities undergraduate majors is 2:1 in both the PRC and US.

Drawing a parallel with the disappearance of .400 hitters as average player performance improved, Kedrosky argues LLM adoption means rising baseline intellectual performance while “true outliers” are more difficult to find and sustain.
NAFTA led to large job losses in historically Democratic low-income US counties, driving a political shift as impact counties swung GOP, driven by white men & non-college whites.

28% of American public school students missed at least 10% of the school year in 2022 up from 15% before the pandemic.  The change was most pronounced in low-achieving school districts.  @natmalkus @AEIecon

Contrary to the common view that the short run burden of trade wars lessens with adjustment over time, taxation of foreign investment goods may mean that U.S. consumption can fall by 2.6%,vs. 0.6% when capital is held fixed, as in a static model.
Long-term real rates over the last 7 centuries show a long downward trend and exhibit no positive correlation with growth in output or population. @krogoff @paul_schmelzing
According to @SWinshi @AEI 20% of Black Americans have been in poverty for three consecutive generations, compared to just 1% of Whites.
Hendrik Bessembinder finds that the best-performing 1,526 global firms (2.4% of total) accounted for all of the $75.7T in net global stock market wealth creation between 1990 and 2020.
@SWinshi: "Deaths of Despair" are largely just opioid use. Drug-related deaths increased significantly since 2000, while suicides & alcohol-related deaths remain at levels similar to the mid-1970s.

While 2-year yields are falling as "expectations for more Fed cuts are building," Brooks notes the back of the yield curve isn't “falling nearly as much, a sign that the debt glut remains very much top of mind for markets.”
40% of births are to unwed mothers, up from 5% in 1960, @SWinshi highlights significant societal shifts in family structures.
Keynesian supply shocks reshape COVID economics: Sectoral shutdowns trigger demand collapse via price effects. 100% shock in half of sectors worse than 50% across all, amplifies through firm exits.

The US imports 80 to 100% of critical minerals, of which 50 to 100% come from China. If new Chinese controls on mineral exports remain in place, Cembalest argues, “the eventual impact on US military, industrial and renewable energy output would be huge.”

High School Sophomore From Highest SES Quartile With A Bottom Half Math Score Has A 56% Of Remaining In Top Half By SES Whereas 10th Grader From Lowest SES Quartile With Top Half Score Has 47% Chance Of Reaching Top Half By SES.

Evidence from CBO projections suggests the TCJA corporate tax cut increased business investment, driving economic growth. @kpomerleau and @DonFSchneider present two revenue-neutral options to finance a permanent extension of the TCJA .
Federal cuts in health care spending and food stamps mean New York State is facing a $4.2B deficit and New York City has a $5B hole in next year's budget.

Challenging @DanielDiMartino’s estimates of the federal fiscal impact of low-skilled immigrants, @David_J_Bier finds that all education groups have a positive impact. Instead of costing $315,000, a 22-year-old high school dropout contributes $45,000.
Manufacturing wage premiums have diverged btw production and nonproduction workers. Nonproduction workers enjoy a 14% wage premium, while production workers' premium has declined to 4% since 2003.

Shelter inflation lags changes in overall CPI due to the delayed adjustment of market rents. This dynamic explains “the lagged and dampened responses of shelter inflation to the post-pandemic surge and then retreat of market-rent inflation.”
In contrast to the March 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine, the US attack on Iran had "essentially no impact on global oil prices," with prices settling at the previous week’s level.

In the mid-1990s, individuals became more likely to cohabit and less likely to marry. After the financial crisis, remaining single became more common and fertility declined sharply. Dissolution rates for both marriage and cohabitation have declined.

Comparing 1980 vs. 2020, Americans became less selective on race and more selective on income and skill in choosing a spouse. “Assortative mating” accounts for ~ 50% of the increase in household income inequality from 1980 to 2020. @paures12

Mark Schneider @AEIecon reviews the ROI of master’s degree programs and finds “vast differences among fields of study and among programs in the same field of study.” He argues that policymakers need to provide accurate ROI metrics to applicants.

.@mjmauboussin reviews ROIC from 1963-2023 including adjustment for intangibles, and finds that “the variance within industries is greater than the variance across industries. The industry is important but does not dictate a firm’s destiny.”
Low-wage workforce totals 53m individuals, 44% of all workers aged 18-64, with 28% aged 25-50 & high school diploma or less, earning $10.22/hr & $17,950/yr.

After a 20-year decline, the share of novel patents produced by “mega firms” began a sharp rebound in 2001, reaching a peak of 18% in 2016. A relative increase in cash holdings since the early 2000s likely facilitated mega firms’ funding of risky R&D.

Research by @PedroBordalo shows households moving btw US cities often pay rent closer to their city of origin due to memory-based norms influencing their choices. This affects economic behavior across different urban markets.

GAFAM acquisition strategy revealed: 175 deals (2015-17) target core segments (36% main business, 82% active areas). Key pattern: 60% of products discontinued, showing R&D/talent focus over market expansion.

Morgan Stanley estimates $2.9T will be spent on the datacenter buildout globally by 2028; $1.5T will require debt financing, $800B of which will be raised from private credit in deals tied to specific assets, including SPVs.
Mexico has overtaken Canada as the largest buyer of American goods. In 2023 Mexico outpaced China to become the largest foreign seller of goods to the US.

Btw the start of the year and the end of July, Germany's DAX has experienced a 33% total return in dollar terms - 4x the S&P 500's gains. Still, Apollo notes, “capital outflows from the US so far have been modest."
Citing a decline in foreign participation in 30-year Treasury auctions in recent months, Torsten Sløk argues that while the risk of a “firesale” of US assets is unlikely, foreigners may stop buying.
Middle-class income support is a new phenomenon: prior to 2000, market income and after-tax income grew together. After 2000, taxes and transfers grew at 3x the rate of market income.

A sharp and steady decline in the GCT scores of Marine Corps officers occurred btw 1980 and 2014. 96% of this is explained by the widening (and weakening) of the applicant pool due to increased college participation. Affirmative action played no role.
Home prices in Palm Beach have doubled since 2020 reaching a total market value of ~ $40B, according to data from Palm Beach County.

The US’s low jobless rate of 4.3% in August may mask some labor market deterioration; 25% of these workers have been out of work for 6m and the unemployment rate for workers 16–24 hit 10.5% in August, the highest level since 2016, excluding the pandemic.

Michael Cembalest @JPMorgan notes that the residential electricity price in CA is >3.5x that of China/India; TX is 2x. US electrical prices have risen vs China and India as renewables’ share of final energy consumption has grown to 8% from 4% in 2010.

The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) acknowledges that increases in the minimum wage disproportionately affect marginal workers, reducing their employment opportunities at three times the rate of adults generally.

Kedrosky argues that a $3.2B junk bond issuance to fund a datacenter and a $30B SPV to finance a Meta datacenter campus place us in the “speculative finance” phase of a Minsky cycle, where firms can service interest but must roll over principal.
Missing growth from creative destruction accounts for ~1/5 of TFP growth in the US from 1983-2013, with 0.54% annual missing growth.

A single parent with one child in Washington DC, earning $11K, receives $68K of government benefits net of taxes for a total after-tax income of $79K. A counterpart, earning $65K, receives $10K of government benefits net of taxes for an after-tax income of $75K. This structure creates little, if any, financial incentive for a low-income parent to work.
Monetary policy has widened racial wealth disparities since 1971, with policy shocks benefiting white households more due to higher financial wealth & interest-rate sensitive assets like equities.

“The labor market appears to be in… a curious kind of balance that results from a marked slowing in both the supply of and demand for workers. Downside risks to employment are rising; risks to inflation are tilted to the upside, a challenging situation.”

The combined purchases of MBS by banks and the Fed lowered the mortgage spread by 81 bps from 2019 to 2024, about 1/2 the 2010-19 average spread. Banks were responsible for 43 bps and the Fed for 38 bps. @idrechs @AlexiSavov @schnabl_econ @DominikSupera

The CBO estimates that the deficit in FY 2025 was (-)1,809B, ~unchanged from the previous year. Both receipts and outlays rose by ~$300B. Customs duties (including tariffs) rose by $118B (153%). Net interest on the debt surpassed $1T for the first time.
Moral self-licensing, a psychological phenomenon where past good deeds allow individuals to engage in unethical behaviors, has significant implications for economic decision-making & policy.
@MarkPerry: Percent increase in median household income per household member since 1967 is +86.6%, almost 2x increase in real median household income of 43.3%.

A natural experiment in the Netherlands, which mandated faster mortgage amortization, revealed significant insights into wealth accumulation. Despite increased debt repayment, there was little-to-no change in non-mortgage savings, indicating no crowding out of private savings.

Citing a number of examples from medicine and meteorology, @cremieuxrecueil argues that “hard-to-explain trend[s]” are often artifacts of shifts in measurement methodology resulting from institutional changes and, in some cases, economic incentives.

Michael Cembalest @jpmorgan notes the 2020/20221 IPO class has performed extremely poorly relative to the overall equity market.  IPO returns since 2010 were highly skewed; if the top 5% were removed, returns were strongly negative vs the market.

New minimum wage research by @David_Neumark reveals a significant trend of negative employment effects, with 79.3% of estimated employment elasticities being negative, particularly for teens, young adults, and less-educated workers.

Noting real value added in US autos is now at an all-time high, Adam Ozimek argues the “death of Detroit” was due not to globalization but to migrating production within the US; Japanese imports did not “nearly destroy” the industry in the early 80s.
Almost 75% of American adults were overweight or obese in 2021, up from ~ 50% in 1990.
Chinese R&D and equipment upgrade subsidies fail to generate a positive impact on firm-level total factor productivity. @nber

Maurice Obstfeld argues that the drivers of declining interest rates since 1980, such as low productivity growth and high safe asset demand relative to supply, have not been offset enough to drive a "big and durable rise in global real interest rates."
Underpayment of workers relative to the minimum wage increases in the aftermath of minimum wage increases and disproportionately impacts workers aged 16-21. @MichaelRStrain @AEIecon

A recent rise in core goods prices, which historically have fallen over time, could be driven by the pricing-in of tariffs. The current uptick in prices is the highest in more than a decade, outside of the 2021–2023 spike.
Research by @SWinshi suggests the expanded Child Tax Credit will lead to 1.5m individuals exiting the workforce, reversing past employment gains & undermining long-term poverty alleviation efforts.
.@davidautor et al. find that the labor-replacing impact of automation innovations has intensified in the past four decades, while the demand-increasing effects of augmentation innovations have not.

The US's new precision strike missile will enable American or Australian Himar platforms to hit moving targets at sea at a range of 310 miles. The system would complicate a contested Chinese invasion or blockade of Taiwan.

Btw 1990–2010, the increase in H-1B holders drove 30–50% of all US productivity growth. Michael Clemens argues if changes to the program reduce the number of H-1B visa holders, it will be "a crippling blow to US innovation and productivity."

In an effort to take advantage of the Trump administration's new nuclear regulatory regime, New York State is launching an effort to build a new nuclear-power facility. Only 5 new commercial reactors have come online in the U.S. since 1991.
Since 2020, Austin's payroll employment and housing prices rose 20% and 44%, respectively, compared with 3% and 48% in NYC. The number of housing units rose 17% in Austin, but just 3% in NYC.

“Even a few billionaires or marquee employers packing up their bags” could put a significant hole in NYC’s budget, given that the city’s top 1% earners pay 40% of the city's income tax and a significant portion of property taxes.

As of May 2024, “home health and personal care aides” with a median hourly wage of $18.26, financed mainly by Medicaid, was the largest job category in NY State by a factor of 2.7:1. This workforce was 21% larger than its pre-pandemic level.
US economy not becoming more monopolistic, 80% of output from sectors with low concentration levels, up from 62% in 2002. @RobertAtkinson

Travel bans for low-level employees continue to broaden in China with some kindergarten teachers, doctors, and employees of state-owned enterprises reporting being ordered to hand in their passports to local authorities.

During the 1950s and ’60s, some 20% of Americans would typically move each year. In 2024, only 7.8% of Americans moved, the lowest rate logged since 1948. Aging, two-earner couples, and high housing costs are all factors stalling geographic mobility.
The US upper middle class has expanded from 12% to nearly 30% of the population since 1979, driven by families earning $100,000 to $350,000 annually.

Nvidia’s Jensen Huang told the FT, "China is going to win the AI race," citing lower Chinese electrical costs and less regulation. His efforts to lobby the WH to allow Nvidia to sell its most advanced chips to Beijing have been unsuccessful to this point.
NYC's top 1% in 2016: 3,500 individuals >$5mm, 35,000 individuals making more than $713,706.

A provision in the reconciliation bill to counter digital services taxation of US firms and the global minimum tax, would give Treasury the authority to tax foreign holders of US assets, and could ultimately reduce demand for US securities.

Kedrosky argues Google's Gemini 3 is "strong, but not transformative,” and ~ comparable to ChatGPT5. "The industry remains on the same trajectory: rising costs, slower progress, and diminishing returns on the problems that matter most."
Howard Marks highlights that between 1988 and 2014, S&P buyers who paid today’s P/E of 22 or above “always earned ten-year returns between plus 2% and minus 2%.”
Greg Mankiw's Blog @GregMankiw: From 1979 to 2007, median real income for tax units increased by only 3.2%, but 36.7% when adjusting for household size & employer-provided health insurance.

The China Shock, plateauing in 2010, adversely impacted U.S. commuting zones through 2019, with a 1.59pp drop in manufacturing employment share from 2001 to 2019. This effect was stronger in areas with fewer college-educated workers. @DavidAutor

The decrease in the gender pay gap in the US originates from the exit of age cohorts with high gender pay gaps, and the entry of recent cohorts with much lower pay gaps, due to declining opportunities for younger men, not large gains for younger women.

Sam Altman said OpenAI doesn't want federal guarantees for its datacenters or a bailout if it fails, but did suggest the Federal government should build its own AI infrastructure, and possibly create a strategic national reserve of computing power.

OpenAI's CFO said the firm is hoping the federal government will "guarantee the financing for chips behind its deals," citing the increase in the cost of debt finance due to the unknown depreciation rates of AI chips.

OpenAI will buy chips from AMD with power demand of 6GW, roughly equal to Singapore’s mean demand. Over the next five years, OpenAI has committed to 23GW of new capacity, which will cost over $1T to bring online.

Opioids account for 44% of the decline in male labor force participation btw 2001-2015. A 10% increase in local opioid prescription rates correlates with a 0.50 percentage point drop in employment rates for prime-age men.
Mandatory spending is projected to rise from 13.1% of GDP in 2017 to 15.2% by 2028, driven by programs like Social Security, Medicare, and Medicaid.
Millennials median net worth is up $650 relative to previous generations at the same point during lifecycle.
A GS analysis finds as of Q2, Chinese wages grew 3.9% y/y, ~ 1pp lower than the official level. The Goldman estimates would be the lowest Chinese wage growth on record, excluding the pandemic period.

French 10-Year OATS now trade at a higher spread than Italy’s equivalent BTPs. John Authers warns that the relative calm is only due to investors' belief that France is too big to fail and the ECB will intervene, implying "a long and steady debasement."

External renminbi loans, deposits, and bond investments have quadrupled over the past five years to $484B, approaching a third of China’s $1.5T of overseas fixed-income assets. Much of the expansion is in the form of trade finance.

US school districts that reduced in-person classes during the pandemic saw significant learning losses, with math pass rates declining by 14.2% points. In contrast, districts with full in-person learning saw a smaller decline of 10.1% points.

Chinese scientific research shows a strong "home bias" where researchers disproportionately cite work from their own country. An adjusted citation ranking places China fourth globally, behind the US, the UK, and Germany. @ClaudiaSteinwen @pierre_azoulay
Research papers & patents have become less disruptive over time. Btw 1945 & 2010, mean disruptiveness of papers declined 91.9%-100%, patents 78.7%-91.5%.

Greater bill issuance and a shorter debt maturity structure will amplify the fiscal impact of Fed policy, "As the level of short-term debt increases, the government’s interest expense becomes more closely tied to the Fed’s policy rate."

Research by @PaulNovosad at @DartmouthCollege finds mortality increase in whites driven by bottom 10% of education distribution, with age-adjusted mortality rising 59-90% for least educated white women and 32-49% for men.

Productivity-pay gap reveals executive bias: 2x firm productivity drives +11% CEO pay vs +4.7% median worker wages. Structured management amplifies compensation inequality within high-performing firms.

BAC internal data show the share of households devoting more than 95% of household income to “necessity spending” increasing 0.3pp to 24% in the first 3 quarters of 2025 compared to the same period in 2024 - ~⅓ of the previous year’s pp rise.

In the US, prices of private vehicles have dropped 40% (quality adjusted) since 1995, but costs of US-produced transit buses have remained flat, exceeding foreign prices. A duopoly in manufacturing, customization, and “Buy America” rules keep costs high.
IT workers accept 2-4% pay cut to gain valuable skills by working at firms with emerging IT systems, offsetting 3-5% of IT investment costs.

China's real estate and related industries account for 29% of its GDP, surpassing Ireland and Spain before their financial crises. A 20% decline in housing could result in a 5-10% drop in GDP output, highlighting significant economic vulnerability.

DoD is mobilizing US missile manufacturers "to double or even quadruple production rates on a breakneck schedule." While the Big Beautiful Bill allocated $25B over the next 5 years, additional money will be required to hit DoD’s production goals.
The US’s Defense Logistics Agency has launched an effort to expand the US stockpile of critical minerals. The Pentagon is seeking another $1B for the effort above the $2B allocated earlier this year.

The Defense Department is taking a 15% stake in MP Materials, the US's largest rare earths miner. In exchange, DoD will guarantee a price floor, protection against the possibility that China will flood the market with minerals, depressing world prices.

Baulos, Garcia, and Heckman conclude that after 50 years, the Perry Preschool Program shows lasting positive effects and that the key element underlying its success is engaging parents and teachers “actively in the learning life of the child.”

Labor’s share of US GDP fell from 64% in 1950 to 59% in 2022, consistent with declines in other countries since 1980. Increasing deployment of capital-augmenting technology appears central to this trend.

A @PIIE report argues it is “unlikely that the magnitude of Korean and Taiwanese semiconductor capex on American territory will be sufficient to meet the [CHIPS Act] target of 20% of global capacity for advanced chips made on US soil by 2030”.

Joseph Wang @FedGuy12 warns a dovish chair and shortened maturity profile of Treasuries risks dollar depreciation and capital flight that could more than offset the boon to risk assets from lower interest rates.

Growth-enhancing policies in seven areas can “lower the trajectory of debt/GDP” but “almost certainly cannot” raise productivity growth from the current 1.1% to the 1.5% that would be required to stabilize the debt without tax or spending changes.

Analysis led by Mark Warshawsky @AEIecon finds that CBO projections significantly underestimate rising healthcare costs, and proposes changing incentives to curb rising demand, and more rapid adoption of new technologies to improve productivity.
College-educated women now make up 28% of the Democratic Party, up from 12% in 1998.

Wage growth for the bottom quartile of American workers slowed to a 3.7% annual rate in June; under that of the top quartile, whose wages grew 4.7%. Since 2017, wage growth for the bottom quartile has generally outpaced that of their higher-earning peers.

Boys raised in low-income families face significantly worse adult outcomes compared to their female counterparts. Data from Opportunity Insights reveals that only 14% of boys from the bottom income quintile attain a college degree by age 25, compared to higher rates for girls.

China’s annual generation of electrical power is 2.5x that of the US. China is self-sufficient in electricity via coal and renewables, whereas the US is self-sufficient in terms of oil and gas but faces capacity constraints in generating electricity.
Rapid credit/asset price growth increases financial crisis likelihood by 40% over 3yrs, compared to 7% in stable periods. @nberpub

Research shows that preferences of top 10% income earners are highly predictive of US policy outcomes, with ~70% accuracy. The 90th income percentile is a proxy for even higher income brackets, with more conservative views on social welfare, taxation & regulation.
41% of those in poverty in 2007 were not poor the following year; however, 1/3 of the 2007 poor were in poverty at least half the years btw 2007-2018.
President Trump's FY 2018 budget proposes $3.6tn in deficit reduction, including $1.5tn from unspecified discretionary cuts & $2.8tn in net mandatory cuts, while reducing revenue by $1tn.

Between January 2020 and May 2024, the regular prices of cheaper US foods and beverages grew at 1.4 times the rate for more expensive ones, adding 8 ppts cumulative price growth relative to premium varieties. @albertocavallo
Intangible investment is increasingly focused on consumer products with limited productivity spillovers, particularly in the pharmaceutical sector.
Private equity firms have amassed $230bn in performance fees since 2006, reflecting their ability to generate returns comparable to public equities.

.@mjmauboussin finds that venture capital, as an asset class, loses more frequently than it wins: 62% percent of global venture capital deals from the mid-1990s to 2018 lost money. But the wins “are so large they offset the losses in the aggregate.”

A 50-state survey finds that inadequate capacity of state DoT staff has been a key driver of higher US infrastructure costs; states that are more reliant on consultants vs. DoT staff spend $70,000 higher cost per lane-mile. @ZLiscow @cailin_slattery
Rising concentration in US manufacturing has been associated with better productivity growth, despite concerns about declining business dynamism.
Productivity growth has not only shifted but stretched, with high-skill workers experiencing faster productivity increases than less-skilled counterparts.

According to research published by @NBER, higher productivity growth in 1989-2017 “is more than sufficient to explain the greater wage growth that more educated workers enjoyed as compared with less educated workers.”

John Fernald and @huiyu_li find since 2023 productivity growth is slightly above the slow post-2004 trend however it remains well under the 1995-2004 pace. TFP growth has outpaced its 2010-19 pace in the post-pandemic period.

Research by @ChadSyverson finds workers generally move from lower to higher productivity firms, but this trend is driven by younger, higher-skilled workers, who are more likely to transition to higher productivity firms.
Public firms’ returns on the book value of assets are down ~ 50% from 1980 and private firms' returns have doubled. @EconTraina @ASollaci @CarterDavisFin
Middle-class incomes grew 60% more than inflation since 1980, prior to the pandemic, according to the Congressional Budget Office @CongressBudgetOffice.

CBO finds that an unfunded permanent expansion of the TCJA would raise debt to 113% of GDP by 2029. Assuming an average interest rate on federal debt of 3.5% in 2025, rising to 3.6% by 2029, the deficit would be 7% of GDP in 2029, up from 6.4% in 2024.

Across zip codes, a one SD increase in disaster risk was associated with $500 higher premiums in 2023, up from $300 in 2018, mainly caused by the pass-through of reinsurance costs. @Key_Z_E @Philipcheesy
@GoldmanSachs reports a 2.85mm workforce decline: aging accounts for 700,000, early retirements for ~850,000, and 1.3mm exits depress labor force participation by 1.1pp from pre-pandemic levels.
.@MichaelRStrain notes that US manufacturing employment declined steadily both before and after "The China Shock," and cautions against the bipartisan turn to industrial policy and protectionism.
Almost none of Amazon's $1.3tn value was built in the private market, with only 3% of Google's & 17% of Facebook's value originating there.

CBO’s upward revisions in projected Federal debt since 2007 reflect two major unforecasted recessions and tax cuts, not unexpected cost increases due to health and aging. Yields are near those of 2007 when debt-to-GDP was ⅓ of today’s level.

Ongoing commodity shock is on track to be a similar order of magnitude as the first oil shock in terms of share of global GDP. US commodities consumers will pay ~ $1T more relative to 2019 or -3.4% of US GDP.
The financial crisis has left a lasting impact on the U.S. economy, with a 13.3% GDP output gap primarily driven by structural issues.
Mortgage originations reached a record high of $1.2tn in 2020Q4, driven by a high share of refinances to borrowers with credit scores over 760. The median credit score for new mortgages was 786.
Blacks overrepresented among offenders in nonfatal violent crimes, 29% of offenders vs 12.5% of population. Whites underrepresented, 52.2% of offenders vs 60.4% of population.

Bruce Meyer finds that when recipients of a variety of US government assistance programs complete Census Bureau surveys, they significantly underreport program participation. Black and Hispanic recipients show the highest rates of underreporting.

Valerie Ramey examines case studies from the US, Singapore, and Australia and finds that temporary transfers like tax rebates “likely provided little or no macroeconomic stimulus in advanced economies,” contradicting influential micro studies.

An analysis of data from the American Time Use Survey documents a 43% reduction in the percentage of Americans who read for pleasure on an average day over a 20-year period, from 28% in 2003 to 16% in 2023.

A JPM analysis finds real income growth for prime-age (25–54) American workers fell to 2% y/y in September. Nominal growth is ~ at its pre-pandemic pace, “but real purchasing power gains are at a relatively low level” given inflation.
The wage gap btw college and non-college workers expanded rapidly in the 1980s, but its growth has slowed significantly since 2000, remaining largely unchanged btw 2010 and 2015.

.@ernietedeschi argues that higher growth, higher debt levels, and greater political risk have most likely driven long-run R* higher than its pre-pandemic levels and higher than the 60bps the median FOMC participant currently projects.

.@ChadBown and team find that China’s tariff reductions in its WTO accession exceeded reciprocity norms, increasing real incomes but driving an incremental 4% decline in labor demand for tradable goods in the rest of the world.

Analysis of multiple data series finds that U.S. male earnings volatility has remained largely stable since the mid-1980s. Despite some short-term fluctuations, long-term volatility trends show minimal change.
Decline in prime age male labor force participation unlikely due to declining compensation, as median hourly compensation rose 12% from 1973-2019.

John Authers notes that Shiller's CAPE (cyclically adjusted price-earnings multiple) hit 40 for the first time since the dot-com bubble burst in 2000. “It never got close to that level over the preceding century, even on the eve of the 1929 Great Crash.”

The short, sharp contraction in 2020 resulted in lasting increases in work-from-home and the government debt, but Stock and Watson “find scant evidence of any long COVID effects at the level of macro dynamics or aggregate, and even sectoral, growth.”
Michael Cembalest notes in 2019, tariffs on Chinese furniture resulted in “almost a 1:1 increase in furniture prices, and US domestic furniture production declined.”

Analysis of a General Mental Ability (GMA) test given to Norwegian soldiers since 1954 suggest that the upward trend in global IQ scores btw 1942-2008 and its subsequent reversal is a testing artifact, not a reflection of real changes in GMA.

Sweden's structural reforms, initiated in response to the 1990s crisis, included adopting flexible exchange rates & inflation targeting, leading to export-led growth & a current account surplus for over a decade. @RichardFreeman @nberpub
Geolocation data from cell phones shows that less than 5% of Americans attend weekly religious services, versus 22% who report they do. @Devin_G_Pope

Internal US migration has significantly decreased, with a notable decline in people moving for new jobs. This trend is not due to demographics but rather a breakdown in traditional migration patterns, as shown by @DanielShoag.
US federal tax rates remain progressive, with negligible rates for the bottom quintile, 11-16% for the middle quintile, and about 33% for the top 1%.
Only 12% of US households are unable to pay an unexpected $400 expense, while 61% can cover it in cash, savings, or credit card paid off at the next statement, according to @FederalReserveStaff.

Regions with high cancer mortality in 1996 saw increased drug-related mortality in non-cancer patients and reliance on public transfers, and a rise in the GOP vote share in elections for the House, president, and governor from the mid-2000s to 2022.
Research shows AI's impact is more pronounced at the firm level, where businesses suited to AI adoption are hiring AI expertise but reducing demand for competing capabilities.
Capital gains tax revenue potential understated: Reform could yield +$1tn/decade above estimates. Lower elasticity (-0.7) + eliminating step-up basis drives gains despite 20→40% rate impact.
Torsten Sløk notes "90% of active managers of public equities underperform their index." He warns that globally equity investors have become highly leveraged to Nvidia.

Unlike short recent time series, three centuries of data on private short-term rates in the U.S. and U.K. show that real r* reverts to a smoothly declining trend following shocks and term premia have risen as inflation volatility fell. @paul_schmelzing
Return on Invested Capital (ROIC) for both high-return and low-return firms tends to regress towards the mean, according to 2016-21 Russel 3000 data.

Noting that revised data show essentially "no growth" in loans from commercial banks over the course of the year, Joseph Wang argues that "outside of the AI-driven capex boom, U.S. businesses do not appear to be embarking upon a capex cycle."
Analysis by @LeeOhanian finds rising inequality btw higher & lower-skilled workers driven by substitutability btw capital & lower-skilled workers, alongside capital-skill complementarity.
Central bank policy explains less than half the variation in interest rates, with the remainder driven by productivity growth, demography, and other factors. @ÒscarJordà.

The unemployment rate for recent male college graduates (22–27) has risen from <5% to 7%. Recent male graduates “are now unemployed at the same rate as their non-graduate counterparts,” while the rate for their female peers is unchanged.

.@JHaltiwanger_UM finds rising US earnings inequality over 1996-2018 reflected both a rising gap in industry-specific wage premia and that “high-wage workers are increasingly sorted to high-wage industries with rising industry premia” and vice versa.
The one-month implied volatility for Treasuries jumped 12.12pp over the past 72 hours, the most on a rolling basis since "Liberation Day."
Research by @ArthurKorteweg and @StefanNagel finds VC start-up investments yield substantial positive abnormal returns, while VC fund returns are near zero when risk-adjusted.

Over the past five years, state regulators nationwide have approved cumulative mean rate increases of 50% for home insurance and 42% for automotive insurance, outpacing the 26% rise in consumer prices over the period.
New estimate finds $600bn in tax and transfer benefits available as cash or near-cash for a single mother with two children.

Since 2022, Saudi Arabia’s budget has switched from surplus to a deficit, now 4% of GDP, which would require a $92bbl oil price -  ~50% above its current level - to eliminate without fiscal reforms. Debt/GDP is 26%, well below KSA’s 40% ceiling.
Net supply of safe assets, particularly US Treasury securities, plays a crucial role in determining global neutral interest rates.
In most states, poor students attend school districts with funding levels similar to those of nonpoor students, challenging the notion of regressive funding.

Investors must generate $5 of value for others to secure $1 for themselves, highlighting the inefficiency in capturing economic gains. This 5:1 ratio underscores the broader economic principle that innovation-driven profits are often dissipated through competition and imitation.
The US allocates 2.8% of GDP to R&D, yet evidence suggests this is insufficient, impacting living standards, health, and national competitiveness.

Global long-term real interest rates have decreased by 450bps over 30 years, driven by demographic forces, higher inequality, and reduced public investment. Central banks are more rate takers than makers.
New Vox eBook by @CoenTeulings and @RichardBaldwin explores secular stagnation, a prolonged period of low economic growth, highlighting its causes and potential solutions.

In 2020 operating a fab in the US cost 30% more than in Taiwan and South Korea and 50% more than in China. The Semiconductor Industry Association estimated that 40–70% of that cost differential was due to relatively higher foreign government subsidies.

The Penn-Wharton model finds that, dynamically scored, the Senate-passed reconciliation bill would increase the sum of primary deficits, which do not include interest, by $3.5T over the next 10 years.

.@Brad_Setser suggests the 2004 US-China “balance of financial terror” has evolved: “In a crisis over Taiwan, China would likely lose access to its reserves–and the G7 countries would see their supply of new cell phones disappear.”

Since 2023:H2, 4-quarter productivity growth has averaged nearly 2.5%, well above the pre-pandemic trend of 1 to 1.25%. The question remains whether this is a new regime or “a temporary surge related to post-pandemic reorganization and consolidation.”
Non-white students received slightly higher funding per pupil by 1982, a trend that has persisted for over 20 years, according to the Tax Policy Center.

In 2024, China State Shipbuilding Corporation built more commercial vessels by tonnage than the entire US shipbuilding industry had built since the end of World War II. @CSIS notes “commercial revenues effectively subsidize China’s naval expansion.”

Ernie Tedeschi estimates tariffs have raised ~$88B in new revenue since January, with the new tariffs raising ~$23B in revenue in August alone. The actual average effective tariff was likely ~11.5% in August relative to 2.4% at the start of the year.

Deming argues that the drop in headcount of software developers aged 22–25 may merely be a reflection of the experience of a particular cohort constituting only 4 years of observations, not the “canary in the coal mine” suggested by Brynjofsson et al.

Reflation in Japan has increased tax revenue, which has improved public finances. Btw 2020 and 2024, gross debt fell from 258% of GDP to 235%. The decline in the government deficit has been offset by a decline in household saving.

Btw 1989 and 2019, US healthcare returns tracked the US tech sector’s returns, albeit with lower volatility. Since 2020, healthcare returns have stagnated as overall US healthcare spending has flatlined at ~17% of GDP since 2008.
Torsten Sløk reports, “The US government currently collects ~$350B in tariffs at an annualized rate, corresponding to 18% of annual household income tax payments.”

QT, increased t-bill issuance, and the govt shutdown are all draining reserves from the banking system, putting upward pressure on money market spreads. Sløk suggests we may be “nearing the point” of switching from an ample to a scarce reserves regime.

Large labor markets are more liquid and improve matching. A 1% increase in market size results in an increase in the 1-year re-employment probability following a firm closure by .14 and .023  for high school and college graduates respectively. @MoisesYi3

Rangvid argues that on top of the slowing of rental-based housing inflation, tariff-driven price increases have been delayed by firms buying ahead of tariffs and stockpiling, basing pricing on historic rather than replacement cost.

@BillDupor, the 2009 Recovery Act's federal highway funds failed to enhance the nation's infrastructure due to states substituting federal dollars for their own spending, with each grant dollar resulting in a state cut of 81 cents.
The U.S. faces a significant construction cost issue in infrastructure projects, with the Seattle tunnel costing ~$1bn per mile, starkly higher than international counterparts.
The average tax rate paid by the top 1% in 1950 was ~ same as today.

A married couple with two average earners retiring in 2020 will receive $407,000 more in benefits from Medicare and Social Security than they paid in taxes, for same couple retiring in 2040 net benefit is $718,000.

.@sc_cath @mjmill611 and @NatashaRSarin calculate that the market value of future Social Security benefits represented 49% of the wealth of the bottom 90% in 2019. Including Social Security, the wealth share of the top 1% had risen only 1.6pp since 1989.

Firefly Aerospace, whose Blue Ghost lander landed on the moon in March, raised $868mm in its IPO. Firefly is working with Northrop Grumman to develop a partially reusable rocket to compete with SpaceX’s Falcon 9.

The AI buildout is being funded by special purpose vehicles (SPVs). Paul Kedrosky warns "if the returns aren't there quickly, the thin equity cushion above datacenter SPV debt holders will be speedily wiped out."
The share of population in middle class decreased by 3% while upper middle class increased by 4% btw 2002-2016.
Mark-to-market losses in the banking system are concentrated in large banks but not the global systemically important banks. @EXjiang
China's economy only 30% as productive as advanced economies, with aggregate TFP growth slowing from 2.8% 1999-2008 to 0.7% in 2009-2018.
According to @AbrahamOthman on @AngelList, fewer than 10% of seed investors outperform the index, highlighting the challenges of picking winners in early-stage investing.
Chinese demand is underlying the gold rally; since January 2024, China has imported a cumulative ~$170B in gold.
As of August 7, reflecting new tariffs on India, the US has an overall effective tariff rate of 17.7%. Dynamically scored, Ernie Tedeschi estimates this tariff regime will raise $2.2T over 2026–2035.
As of July 28, the US has an effective tariff rate of 17.3% including the new 15% rate for the EU. Dynamically scored, Ernie Tedeschi estimates this regime will raise $2.3T over 2026–2035.

As of July 7, the US has an effective tariff rate of 17.6%, now reflecting a 20% tariff on Vietnam and 25% tariffs on Japan and South Korea. Dynamically scored, this regime will likely raise $2.2T over 2026–2035.

The top-earning men in Finland and Norway score 1 standard deviation higher in cognitive ability than median earners. The ability curve is steepest at the top of the earnings range. @MarkoTervio @olerogeberg
New industries grow rapidly, then experience a significant shakeout, with 38 of 46 products showing a net decrease of 52% in producers by 1981.

GS estimates that for every 1pp export-driven increase in Chinese GDP, advanced economies experience a 0.1–0.3pp drag. “China Shock 2.0 is likely to crowd out tech-intensive, high-value-added manufacturing activity in the rest of the world.”
S&P 500 Capital Expenditures Dollars per Share 1994-2018.
