Foreign tourist arrivals in the US–especially from Europe–remain buoyant. Italy posted a new all-time high in April 2025; data provide evidence contrary to the narrative warning of a collapse in travel to the US.

There is currently $1.66T of outstanding Federal student loan debt. The 6mm borrowers aged 50 to 61 who still have Federal student loans outstanding have a mean balance of $47,857, the highest of any age cohort.

The 2.1M year-round, full-time workers in the United States who first came to the country on a student visa earn a median salary of $115,000, 32% higher than native-born counterparts, and are twice as likely to work in R&D or to become entrepreneurs.

COVID-19 pandemic has intensified substance abuse, contributing to a decline in labor force participation among prime-age workers. Substance abuse, particularly involving opioids and meth, accounts for up to 26% of a 1.3pp drop in participation, with 391,000 additional non-participants linked to pandemic-related increases in substance use.
Andrew Lees @MacrostrategyP argues that the US current account deficit is being funded in part by the flight of capital from Europe, which cannot continue indefinitely.

Michael Cembalest notes that the 10 largest American stocks represent ~ 35% of market capitalization. Earnings are “more or less keeping pace, particularly when measured based on forward earnings estimates.”

According to @FederalReserveBank of New York, superstar cities have seen higher housing price appreciation over 150 years, but total returns are lower due to higher rent returns in non-superstar cities.

.@JHaltiwanger_UM @UpdatedPriors document the continued high rate of new business formation by “likely employers” since 2020, and argue that “the pandemic and its aftermath featured a surge in genuine entrepreneurial employer business creation.”

Meta, Microsoft, and Alphabet’s capex as a percent of revenue (21–35%) are now on par with utilities’ global mean and AT&T’s at the height of the telecom bubble. Kai Wu notes the “telecom index still remains -60% below its dot-com high 25 years later.”

AI programs are making progress in solving freelance software engineering tasks, but they are still less capable than experienced engineers. The top-performing model successfully completed tasks worth $208k on Upwork, out of 1,400 tasks worth $1mm.

Taiwan’s dollar surged more than 2% as its large life insurance and export sectors moved to hedge US dollar weakness. Taiwan’s currency has gained 12% this year, driven by foreign inflows and significant US dollar selling by local exporters.

The conclusion of the trade war amounts to an effective tax hike worth about 1% of GDP, yielding annual revenue between $450B and $600B, Wang suggests. The tariffs will have uneven short-term economic impacts, with autos and clothing bearing the brunt.

Paul Kedrosky argues the tariff regime is similar to a backdoor VAT and is not "so bad, if the alternative real distortion is structural deficits." He notes a VAT at half the mean OECD level would “nearly zero out” the current U.S. deficit.

The current tariff regime will raise ~$2.8T net new revenue through 2034, conventionally scored, according to a CRFB estimate. “Those who wish to reduce or reverse the tariffs should put forward alternative sources of deficit reduction to replace them.”

Tariffs generated $30B in August 2025; $27B of that was new revenue, and the current regime could raise ~$2T over the next decade. Clausing/Obstfeld’s analysis finds that the welfare losses associated with the tariffs offset over a third of the revenue.
US aluminum prices are now 48% higher than Europe’s and 56% higher than Japan’s.
Research by @ErikHurst highlights task-based discrimination, where Black workers are underrepresented in high-paying Abstract tasks, widening the racial wage gap since 1980.
.@KyleLHandley argues the "China Shock" has likely run its course; as of 2020 import penetration was well under the 2000-2010 and 2010-2018 trends.
Current measures of wealth/income inequality overstate lifetime spending inequality due to more equal distribution of human wealth & progressive fiscal policies. @LaurenceKotlikoff @WSJ.
Inventors are significantly less likely to locate in states with higher taxes, with an elasticity to the net-of-tax rate of 0.11 for local inventors and 1.23 for non-local inventors.
High-income workers are notably responsive to tax rates when making location decisions, raising questions about tax policy's impact on migration patterns & local economies.
Top tax rates significantly influence where "superstar" inventors locate, with a 10% decrease in top tax rates potentially retaining 1% more domestic and attracting 38% more foreign inventors.
CBO analysis reveals significant disparities in effective tax rates on capital income, with a base case rate of 13.8%.

In Sweden and Denmark, a 1pp increase in the mean wealth tax reduced the stock of rich taxpayers by 2%. When an entrepreneur subject to the wealth tax emigrates, employment in their businesses drops by 33%, and tax payments by 50%. @MathildeMunoz

Citing 25% growth in the STEM share of jobs and 50% drop in retail share since 2010, @ProfDavidDeming and @LHSummers suggest “AI could be a general-purpose technology on the scale of prior disruptive innovations” like steam power and electricity.

.@ProfDavidDeming and @LHSummers find higher “churn” in the labor market over 2010-2024 relative to 1990-2019. Growth in low-paid service jobs has “stalled.” Employment in STEM has risen by more than 50%, and retail sales jobs have declined by 25%.
80% of technologies improve at <25% a year.

Bain notes that anticipated capital investment in data centers is $500B annually.  Bain’s analysis of sustainable ratios of capex to revenue for cloud service providers suggests that $500B of annual capex corresponds to $2T in annual revenue and cost savings, a number well short of their most optimistic scenario.

According to a long-running survey, the number of high school seniors reporting they were "very happy" fell from 24.8% in 2007 to 17.9% in 2019 and 12.7% in 2023. Jean Twenge cautions, "The constant pressure of social media [is] a trap of unhappiness."

Telemigration impact remains modest: US service imports from India/China/Brazil/Canada under $11bn (2019). Data contradicts offshore service job exodus concerns. Key metric shows limited displacement effect.

Data shows income inequality, as measured by the Gini coefficient, has seen only modest increases over the past few decades. From 1990 to 2020, the Gini coefficient for household income rose from 0.43 to 0.48, a change of just 0.05 points. @SWinshi

If the CPS-implied drop in the US immigrant population of 2.2mm were accurate, Jed Kolko argues, “overall U.S. unemployment would be at a 72-year low of 2.6% and the economy would be dangerously overheating.”

The 2008 financial crisis was driven by a European banking glut rather than an Asian savings glut, according to @RobertMcCauley @Bank_for_International_Settlements. European banks took on credit and maturity risk by purchasing riskier US mortgage bonds.
The proportion of Americans identifying as white and Christian has seen a significant decline over the past few decades, dropping from 65% in 1996 to 54% in 2006, and further to 43% by 2017.

The share prices of AI-related firms as a multiple of forward earnings have seen a downtick as some investors worry about rising leverage. AI-related companies issued $139B of debt so far this year, or 9% of all investor-grade issuance.

Btw 2016 and 2023, Alphabet, Amazon, Meta and Microsoft's free cash flow and net earnings ~ tracked each other; since 2023, net earnings have risen 73% and free cash flow has declined by 30% due to the AI buildout.
17% of American workers are low marginal product workers, contributing less to output relative to their employment cost, with 70% leaving their jobs within a year.
Pew Research Center claims the middle class is being hollowed out, but 7 of the 11-point decline is driven by families whose income moved upwards.

Michael Lange argues Mamdani’s winning coalition was one of the “in-between,” made up of working, middle, and upper-middle-class renters spanning white, Hispanic, and Asian neighborhoods. Cuomo slimly prevailed among the rich and the poor.

The proposed expansion of the Child Tax Credit (CTC) under the American Families Plan is expected to significantly impact labor supply, with Bruce Meyer estimating that 1.5m workers, or 2.6% of all working parents, will exit the labor force.

Heckman et al, using two longitudinal data sets with a rich set of controls, find that participation in varsity athletics raises rates of high school and college attendance and graduation, as well as earnings, especially for disadvantaged students.
American public firms have reduced their white-collar workforce by 3.5% over the past three years; managers and executives were more impacted, falling 6.1% and 4.6%, respectively, over the period.
Since the launch of ChatGPT in November 2022, AI related stocks have accounted for 75% of S&P 500 returns, 79% of earnings growth, and 90% of capital spending (Capex and R&D) growth.

In spite of a bill that the CBO forecasts will add $2.4T to US budget deficits over the next 10 years and a Moody’s downgrade, investors bid 2.52x the offer in yesterday’s Treasury auction, ”a worrying sign for fiscal conservatives,” Burgess writes.

American steel manufacturers have gained 7pp of market share since 2015 and are expanding domestic capacity by ~25% of 2024’s domestic production, though American steel prices are the highest globally.
ACA will reduce total hours worked on net by 1.4-2% btw 2017-2024, primarily due to workers opting to supply less labor in response to new taxes & incentives, as well as financial benefits.

.@USCBO projects a deficit of 6.2% of GDP in 2025, down from 6.6% in 2024. Outlays at 23.3% of GDP would exceed the long-term mean by 2.2pp; revenue of 17.1% is just 0.2pp under its long-term mean. Projections beyond 2025 assume the expiration of TCJA.
US financial assets benefit from a "Safe Harbor Premium" due to perceived lower risk. @ernietedeschi argues that US “shadow risk” increased 20-25 bps between 2016-20.
@USCBO estimates that a $15/hr minimum wage by 2025 would reduce workforce by 1.4mm workers, or 0.9% of workforce, by 2025.

John Cogan finds federal budget deficits are driven by items “originally considered to be the responsibility of state and local governments or private-sector charities.” In 1950 Federal spending on these activities was 2% of GDP; by 2019 it was 14%.

Adair Turner, citing South Korea’s continued ability to innovate despite plummeting fertility, argues that population decline doesn't necessarily imply a slowdown in growth; only a small fraction of the population drives technological advances.
Government R&D spending has historically coincided with productivity & GDP growth, but direct impact on economic growth remains unclear.

China’s state commercial banks added $47 billion to their net foreign asset position in June. Brad Setser argues “the preponderance of evidence suggests that China has been resisting pressure on its currency to appreciate” against the dollar.

An experiment in which a non-profit gave low-income Americans a tax-free $1k/month for 3 years showed little effect on political engagement, conservatism, or trust in democratic governance, but some increased belief in the value of work. @AlexBartik
Single parent family poverty declined by 62% btw 1995 and 2016, according to the Comprehensive Income Dataset (CID). @KevinCorinth
Research shifted from corporate labs to startups & universities hasn't fully compensated for decline of corporate labs, impacting innovation & economic growth.

Reihan Salam argues that NYC’s incoming mayor will take office with “the clock on his program already five minutes to midnight,” citing the erosion of the tax base relative to outlays and the fact that net job growth has been driven by Medicaid spending.
.@charlesmurray argues that urban disorder has increased since 2013, when cities abandoned broken-windows policing.
Physical labor-oriented firms have invested less in information technology and have only improved productivity 0.7% per year.
Secrecy During WWII Reduced Commercialization/Diffusion Of Tech Change.
Child allowances could reduce employment rates among single mothers by 3-4% points, driven by income effects that make it easier for parents not to work. @SWinshi, American Enterprise Institute.

US consumer sentiment is significantly lower than expected based on unemployment and inflation. Alternative measures of inflation that include borrowing costs can account for almost three quarters of this gap. @MA_Bolhuis @juddcramer @LHSummers
.@swinshi @AEIecon finds faults with @oren_cass analysis and argues that it has become easier for a male earner to support a family than it was in 1985. @jmhorp @JonahDispatch

The economic impact of COVID-19 is estimated at $16tn, 90% of US GDP. Lost GDP over the next decade totals $7.6tn, while excess deaths are valued at $4.4tn. @DavidCutler @LHSummers, Journal of the American Medical Association.
Over 3m excess retirements contributed to more than half of the 5.25m exits from the labor force by Q2 2021, according to @MiguelFariaeCastro of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis.

The share of lending in the form of “private credit” has grown dramatically since the financial crisis. Private credit may now be a $1.5 trillion industry that is at least as large as the syndicated loans market. @jared_ellias and Elisabeth de Fontenay

First Amendment shapes education economics: Compelled speech restrictions affect $700bn public education sector. CRT debate parallels prayer/pledge cases, signals potential funding/resource allocation shifts

After adjusting Treasury data for an estimated undercount of ~$1.4T suggested by regulatory data, a Federal Reserve analysis finds hedge funds domiciled in the Cayman Islands are, increasingly, the marginal foreign buyers of Treasury notes and bonds.

Labor productivity in the restaurant industry rose sharply during the pandemic and remains 10-15% higher than pre-Covid, driven by take-out and delivery. The fraction of customers spending 10 minutes or less in-house rose 10 ppt. @Austan_Goolsbee

In a 776-person field experiment at P&G on real product innovation tasks, individuals using AI delivered solutions with higher average quality than teams without AI, and performed almost as well as teams using AI.
In 2024, Americans aged 15–24 spent 70% less time attending or hosting parties than they did in 2003 according to the American Time Use Survey.
The world's 2024 total fertility rate (TFR) was likely ~2.17, below the replacement rate of 2.21, notes Jesús Fernández-Villaverde, intensifying demographic challenges posed by the “welfare state.”

Voters under the age of 45, 46% of registered voters in New York City, made up ~43% of voters in the mayor’s race. In neighborhoods where the nonwhite population is shrinking, Mamdani won by more than 50pp.

Since Powell’s Jackson Hole speech, currencies issued by countries with low debt burdens are outperforming the currencies of high-debt countries. Brooks projects that Sweden's “undervalued” Krona will emerge as a key safe-haven currency going forward.

Btw 1979 and 2016, market income for the top quintile grew by 101%, while the bottom quintile saw a modest increase of 32%. The data suggests that policy interventions may be necessary to address the growing economic divide.

From 2019 to 2021, income after transfers and taxes for the top quintile grew by 19% (largely from realized capital gains), the bottom quintile grew by 17% (primarily from temporary transfers), and the middle quintiles by 5%.

.@kevincorinth @Tqorourke @swinship find that social capital —the value inherent in relationships— has a strong positive relationship with socioeconomic status, including market income and education. @AEI
The CBO estimates that increasing government spending by 5-10% of GDP could reduce GDP by 3-10% by 2030, depending on financing methods.
Analysis by @CaseyMulligan suggests expanded UI programs reduced US employment by 6-10m jobs due to full bonus & 3-5m jobs due to half bonus.
Private equity buyouts lead to a 1.7% decline in compensation per worker, but labor productivity increases by an average of 8% post-buyout.

France: 2nd-gen immigrants show worse job outcomes vs 1st-gen, unlike Germany/UK where gaps stay stable. Women's employment gaps narrow across all 3 nations. Points to distinct French integration policy challenges.

Roland Fryer reports on his research that found educational attainment, followed by traits like resilience, self-esteem and conscientiousness were the strongest predictors of intergenerational mobility in the US.
Germany's compulsory schooling reform added a 9th grade, increasing numeracy skills by 0.2 standard deviations for basic-track students, but had no impact on literacy skills.

Using CPS data from 1991-2013, Boskin, Elnahal, and Zhang find that redistribution policy attenuates market income shifts most strongly at the middle-income quintile, consistent with the median voter theory.

Between 1979 and 2022 prime-age men in the bottom quintile saw their inflation-adjusted market income rise 10%, to an all-time high of $22,800/year. Their female counterparts saw their market income rise 63% to $20,300/year. @swinshi
CBO estimates that $10.10 and $9.00 minimum wage options would reduce employment by ~500,000 or 100,000 workers.

West Point professor Kyle Greenberg et al. find that the integration of women into the U.S. military had negligible effects on men's performance, but worsened men’s perceptions of workplace quality in units with at least one female officer.
Immigration restrictions led to US-born workers moving to urban areas, replacing immigrants, and a shift to capital-intensive agriculture in rural areas, reducing labor demand and farm wages.

Chang et al find that in the PSID, higher parental income and living in an intact family during middle childhood and adolescence are more predictive of favorable child outcomes than income and family structure during early childhood.

Raising the federal minimum wage to $15 by 2025 would result in a 0.8% reduction in employment, equating to 1.3m fewer jobs in an average week, according to @CBOWashington. Real family income is expected to decline by 0.1%, or $9bn.

Analysis by @HenrikKleven reveals welfare reform, not EITC, drove significant employment gains for single mothers in the 1990s, with the EITC's complex structure limiting its effectiveness in boosting labor supply.
Current explanations for the decline in labor share sum to 3-4 times the actual decline, according to @GeneGrossman @nberpubs.

Since the 1960s labor market fluctuations have become more uniform across states, helping to make interstate migration less important in cyclical adjustments.  @A_Fieldhouse @D_Munro_Econ @ChristofferKoch

.@RyanMKellogg forecasts that “green” policies implying a drop in oil demand to 0 by 2099 will cause producers to reduce investment and near-term production, refuting the “green paradox” of accelerated near-term extraction and worsening climate change.

John Burn-Murdoch hypothesizes that rising populism reflects “an unveiling of the electorate’s unfiltered inclinations,” with extreme views, both left and right, better reflected in social, as opposed to traditional, media.

Wage growth of the bottom quartile of American workers slowed to a 3.7% annual rate in June, below that of the top quartile, whose wages grew 4.7%. Since 2015, wage growth for the bottom quartile has generally outpaced that of their higher-earning peers.
A 10% increase in state-level effective minimum wage reduces vacancies by 2.4% in the same quarter & 4.5% a year later in at-risk occupations.

Deposits - especially uninsured deposits that create run risk - have risen sharply, while banks with the most rapid growth in deposits have shifted assets away from lending towards longer-term MBS and Treasuries. @lauramnicolae

Income inequality rose markedly btw 1980-2010, but consumption inequality remained stable. Leisure inequality also widened, with low-educated men gaining 2.5 hours of leisure per week by 2007, while high-educated men saw a 1.2-hour decline.
Since the beginning of 2021, the top 10 stocks in the S&P 500 by market cap accounted for 54% of the index’s increase in market capitalization.
Internal board notes show Freddie and Fannie were highly competitive with each other.

John Authers notes it is almost “certain” the Federal Reserve will cut the FFR this week, though September headline and core CPI inflation both came in at a 3% annual rate. Rental inflation continues to fall, but further pressure from tariffs looms.
Between 2014 and 2024, rural areas in the EU lost 8.3% of its population due to falling birth rates and internal migration. The OECD warns this “creates political discontent.”

Ernie Tedeschi estimates that the Senate's version of the reconciliation bill (conventionally scored) will cost $3T over the 2025–2034 window. Interest payments rise to 3.8% of GDP in 2030 relative to 3.6% under CBO's current law baseline.

An AEI analysis finds immigrants with a high school degree or less have a negative net fiscal impact. These immigrants are less of a burden than their native peers as they don’t qualify for as much public assistance.

An EC study of European competitiveness finds that EU gross value-added per hour worked increased by 0.7%/year from 2000-19, vs. 1.2%/year in the US. “Europe is lagging in the breakthrough digital technologies that will drive growth in the future.”

Looking fwd 50 years, Mankiw forecasts “heavy handed" state intervention in competitive US markets (such as industrial policy, tariffs and minimum wages) will decline, arguing “The arc of the economic universe is long, but it bends toward efficiency.”
25 US cities have generated most job growth since the Great Recession, driven by high-growth industries & young, educated workforces. These cities could capture 60% of US job growth through 2030.

A large dataset on preferences of workers and capability assessments from AI experts suggests a mismatch between actual AI usage by task and a Human Agency Scale that rates its suitability to the task, taking into account both tastes and capabilities.

An analysis of census data finds residents of the mean “prosperous” (top-quintile) county live 5.3 years longer than those in the mean “distressed” (bottom-quintile) one, with the discrepancy between the top and bottom percentiles widening to 8 years.
China’s DeepSeek costs 20–40x less per million “input tokens” than OpenAI’s ChatGPT.

In 75 years, 20% of the world's population is projected to live in Pakistan, Nigeria, the DRC, Ethiopia and Tanzania. Noah Smith notes, "More and more of humanity is going to live in a few big countries that can't manage themselves."

A GS analysis suggests 5–15% of the American population engages in “gig work,” but only 2–4% of the population participates in platform-based gig work like Uber. Overall, platform gig workers work 14 hours a week and earn ~$18 an hour.
American companies operate almost two-thirds of A.I. data centers globally. Only 16% of nations have AI data centers.
In 2023 there were 2.7mm asylum claims made in OECD countries, far more than the 1.7mm at the height of the Syrian Civil War. The claimants are largely migrating for economic reasons.

Long Japanese yields spiked, and the Yen fell in response to the likely new prime minister’s “reputation as a fiscal dove.” Robin Brooks describes the divergence btw 10y20y fwd and simple 10-year yields as “scary.”

Only one country – Switzerland – has seen 30-year yields fall since January 2024 and the start of the cutting cycle. Robin Brooks suggests this implies “there’s a slow-motion run on government debt” underway.
The labor share of GDP has significantly declined in 42 of 59 countries studied, including China, India, and Mexico, as documented by economists @LoukasKarabarbounis and @BrentNeiman.
New Fed research suggests the US equilibrium real interest rate is likely negative, driven by global economic factors, with estimates showing a decline from ~2% in the mid-1990s to ~0% in 2019.
Capital flow paradox hits US productivity: Cheap foreign capital drives shift from tradable to non-tradable sectors, reducing innovation investment and dampening productivity growth post-2000.

US capital inflows target non-tradable sectors, depressing tradable sectors & slowing US innovation, according to @MartinWolf Working Paper. This dynamic creates a feedback loop where reduced innovation in the US leads to slower global growth.
Almost 200 new American factories have come online since mid-2023, and Torsten Sløk estimates there is a $590B pipeline of new domestic advanced manufacturing projects.

Research by @AndrewsDan @ChiaraCriscuolo @PeterGal finds divergence btw frontier & laggard firms reflects a slowdown in diffusion process, potentially due to higher costs for laggard firms transitioning to an idea-based economy.

Noting that “the dividing line between EM and G10 [yields] is already getting blurred,” Brooks argues advanced economies are beginning to resemble EMs with “simplistic populism, reckless fiscal policy, and fiscal dominance of their central banks.”
The global savings glut, driven by policy choices, has led to macroeconomic imbalances & high savings rates suppressing demand & hindering investment. @JonTurek
Oracle is currently earning 14% gross margins from renting out Nvidia's cutting-edge Blackwell chip. Paul Kedrosky notes, "That’s worse than the gross margins of many nontech retail businesses."
Since Powell's Jackson speech, gold has risen 13% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.
The Census Bureau's Official Poverty Measure (OPM) overestimates poverty by excluding major government transfer programs & tax credits from income calculations. @MattWeidinger

While the crime rate has fallen in the US and UK, incidents of fare evasion, driving offenses, shoplifting, and dog attacks have risen since the pandemic. As public disorder has increased, the % of those who believe overall crime has increased has risen.
The social safety net saw increased transfers across income groups during the Great Recession, but the increase was not strongly progressive within low-income populations.
The retired share of the US population was 1.5pp above pre-pandemic trend in Oct 2022, with 3.5mm retirees accounting for nearly all of the shortfall in LFP rates.

In October 2022, the retired share of the American population was 1½ percentage points above its pre-pandemic trend. These 3.5 million workers account for essentially all of the shortfall in labor force participation rates. @federalreserve
The US economy experienced a significant reversal in the demand for cognitive skills around 2000, pushing down wages for high-school graduates & increasing employment in low-skilled manual jobs.

Transfer payments made up 18% of all US personal income in 2022, up from 8% in 1970. Social Security/Medicare made up 56% of the increase from 1970 to 2022, and income maintenance programs/Medicaid accounted for 35%. @kenanfikri @BenGlasner
The Green New Deal is estimated to cost btw $52.6tn and $94.4tn over a decade, according to @DougHoltzEakin.
Btw 1960-2020, total wage bill paid to managers in the US more than doubled from 15% to 32%, also leading to an uptick in age of peak earnings.

In county survey data of 12,316 female respondents born btw 1985 and 1989, those who identify as conservative have a completed fertility rate of 2.1, relative to moderates’ rates of 1.9, and liberals’ 1.7.
The US upper middle class grew from 13% in 1979 to 29% in 2014, with the bottom 3 income groups' share of income declining from 70% to 37%.

Historically, American women have had higher levels of religiosity than men. Between 2014 and 2024, however, the share of women 18–24 who identify as religiously unaffiliated rose 10pp to 43%, ~on par with their male peers’ 41%.

A new IMF report “finally acknowledges” that China’s goods trade balance and its investment income balance are far too low relative to customs data and data on foreign assets and liabilities. China’s deficit is likely > $1T, 2x its official estimate.
According to @GoldmanSachs, foreign-born labor force is rebounding from 2.8mm below trend in September 2020 to 1.2mm below trend in March 2022.
Tim Krupa from @GoldmanSachs reports that the foreign-born labor force is rebounding from 2.8M below trend in September 2020 to 1.2M below trend in March 2022.
The American Families Plan would add 6.2mm households to federal entitlement rolls, marking a historic shift where over 50% of non-elderly U.S. households receive benefits.
State-level R&D tax credits boost entrepreneurship by 7% in net new business formation rates 5yrs post-enactment, rising 20% over a decade. @CatherineFazio

The economy has added over 7m jobs since the 2016 election, surpassing the 1.9m forecasted by the CBO. Wage growth for historically disadvantaged groups has outpaced that of more advantaged groups, with a 10.6% increase in nominal wages since the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act.
Corrado finds that real welfare gains are likely understated due to mismeasurement of “consumer digital access services.”

US industry concentration rose from 1977 to 2013, driven by a new industrial revolution in services, retail, and wholesale sectors, where top firms adopted technologies to standardize & scale non-traded services.

Cocaine is making a comeback, driven by European demand which has overtaken the US as the world’s largest market. In Columbia, the world’s largest producer, cocaine production rose 53% btw 2022 and 2023.

The dollar’s share in official currency reserves, FX transaction volume, and foreign currency debt instruments and related measures suggest little threat to its international dominance as store of value, unit of account, and means of payment.

The 2006 World Bank Enterprise Survey shows the greatest prevalence of female entrepreneurship in middle-income countries, “where the returns to entrepreneurship are high enough to offset gender-based costs and both sexes typically form simple firms.”

Matt Klein notes wage growth remains persistently 1–1.5pp faster than its pre-pandemic level, consistent with an inflation rate of ~3% before the impact of tariffs, which should be limited as imported goods are a small part of the US consumption basket.

Paul Kedrosky estimates given datacenter’s high deprecation rates - the replacement cycle for GPUs is 3 to 4 years - to be profitable, the return “must exceed the risk-adjusted, weighted average cost of capital, which is 12–14%.”

.@CliffordAsness notes large and prolonged swings in US stock market valuations since 1990, and contends that the market has become “less informationally efficient.” He advocates having “the longest time horizon possible” to wait out bubbles.
Rapid credit growth predicts below-average equity returns, with high credit growth associated with 6.8% returns vs 11.6% when growth is low.
A universal child care program in Quebec led to persistent negative impacts on noncognitive skills, higher crime rates, particularly among boys

Affirmative action bans by several states have increased racial/ethnic disparities in both college degree completion and earnings among minority women. Effects on minority men are more ambiguous. @FranciscaAntman

A new @USCBO analysis argues rising government debt may drive significant crowding out going forward: "In CBO’s assessment, every additional dollar of deficit-financed spending reduces private investment by 33 cents."
Lost schooling has significant long-term economic costs. A 1966-67 German school year reduction led to 5% lifetime income loss for affected students. @JonHilsenrath @WSJ.
New cohorts of college graduates have experienced lower employment rates, 3-4% lower than pre-2005 trends, since 2005. @JesseRothstein

Examining official data and company financials, Matt Klein estimates “U.S. GDP would be about 0.4% higher than currently reported…if the [capex] of Amazon, Google, Meta, Microsoft, and Oracle were fully incorporated into the official data.”

The market-implied 10-year real yield expected ten years from now is ~ 3%, its highest level since 2010, and ~2x what it was in early 2023. The real 20-year yield expected in 20 years is even higher, signalling high real yields for many years to come.

In September, 44% of middle-income Americans reported they were financially "worse off" than a year ago, while 23% said they were "better off," ~ unchanged from last September, when 48% reported being "worse off" versus 24% who said "better off."

@KatherineGuyot ~90% of middle-class income growth btw 1979-2018 driven by higher female wages & hours worked. The average middle-class married couple with children now works 3,446 hours annually, up by over 600 hours since 1975.

Aging populations and anti-immigration rhetoric in rich countries are forcing companies building electricity infrastructure to find creative solutions to meet surging demand. The US is unable to fill a third of its 400k+ new annual engineering roles.
Between 1992 and 2025, the US economy significantly decarbonized; the ratio of carbon dioxide emissions to GDP fell from ~ .44 to ~.19, largely being driven by the replacement of coal by natural gas.

Between 2019 and 2023, the mean US distance from work rose from 15 to 26 miles; 12% of employees hired after March 2020 live at least 50 miles from their employers, 3x the % in 2019. High taxes and house prices predicted relocation. @I_Am_NickBloom
North American firms have seen a significant rise in profitability, with growth rates twice that of emerging market counterparts, driven by strategic investments in tech & innovation.

The manufacturing share of US employment has fallen from its 1944 peak of ~38% to its current level of <10%. Far from implying that “the US doesn’t make things anymore,” this reflects technical progress; manufacturing output is at its historical max.
US individuals with Nordic ancestry earn 30% more than average Americans and 50% more than their Nordic counterparts, highlighting factors beyond public policy that contribute to income disparities.
The share of working-age Americans with a college degree is now 20% higher in urban areas than rural ones, a significant increase from a 5% gap in 1970.
By 2075, India and China are projected to surpass the US in GDP size, yet the US will maintain a significant lead in real per capita GDP, increasing from $69k in 2021 to $132k.
Hedge funds retained 63.6% of cumulative gross returns btw 1995-2016, leaving investors with 36 cents per dollar of gross excess returns.

.@FiveThirtyEight analyst @geoffreyvs finds that Fetterman’s margin of victory was provided by non-college white voters: Fetterman polled 7pp better than Biden in counties dominated by non-college whites.

.@alexeymakarin and team argue that political contributions and advertising spending by fossil fuel interest groups contributed to the post-Chernobyl decline in nuclear power, increasing air pollution and costing 318 million life years globally.
A Analysis of syllabi from leading education schools reveals a significant left-leaning bias in assigned readings, with 33 mislabeled as scientific & 27 displaying explicit political intent.

Over the next 25 years, China's working-age population will fall by over 20%, while the US’s will continue to grow. “Exponential decay of population numbers over a long period of time can transform the international stage and shift the global balance.”

A McKinsey analysis finds btw 2011–2019, 5% of American firms drove ~80% of real gross value added per worker gains. The US sample had 3x the number of leading firms relative to “stragglers” than did Germany and the UK who were almost at par.

Medicaid cuts are a potential liability for the GOP. The GOP represented 26 of the 100 lowest-income House districts in 2009 and 56 in 2023. Of the 145 districts most dependent on Medicaid, the % represented by Republicans has more than doubled to ~37%.
The Restrepo Papers explore the dynamic interplay btw automation & human labor, highlighting its implications for economic growth, factor shares, & employment.

.@ProfDavidDeming and team found that 39% of the US population aged 18-64 used generative AI in August, faster adoption than either the PC or the internet. However, only 0.5-3.5% of US work hours are currently assisted by AI.
Electricity supplies nearly 30% of China’s energy use today and is growing at an annual rate of 6%. In the US, electricity accounts for 22% of energy use and is growing at an annual rate of 0.6%.
Had 2009 expansion ended in 2014, real wages at median and 20th percentile would have been under 2007 level @MichaelStrain @nberpubs.
Since Powell’s Jackson speech, gold has risen 16% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.
Decline in Labor Force Participation among prime age men driven by "in-and-outs" who temporarily exit the labor force for leisure activities, without affecting lifetime earnings.

De Loecker et al. found that aggregate markups surged from 18% to ~ 67% from 1980–2014. This comment argues that much of this finding is due to DEU’s deletion of observations with missing values for SG&A, and the rest is limited to Finance and Insurance.
Reallocating activity to its pre-1986 Tax Reform accounts for 1/3 decline in corporate sector labor share from 1978 to 2017.
Over the past decade, passive equity funds and ETFs have seen $2.8T of inflows relative to $3T outflows from actively managed funds. The median S&P 500 firm passive ownership share has risen to 26%.
In 2024, solar and wind generated 15% of global electrical production and 63% of the growth of electrical output since 2019.
Star firms associated with market power but star firms produce and invest more per dollar of invested capital.
Recessions cause persistent increases in inequality as low-skilled men face a double-whammy: losing skills while unemployed & facing declining skill prices.

Goldman finds shortening the weighted average maturity (WAM) of debt would have a "limited effect" in lowering the interest burden. Given the current US term structure, one added rate cut would have a bigger effect than a 2-year shortening of WAM.

Mark Warshawsky simulates the performance of government pensions based on the past ten-year history of bond and stock returns. At the 25th percentile of historical returns, few plans are fully funded, and many are below 50% funding. @AEIecon
US business startups and employment dynamism have declined, with the share of employment by young firms decreasing by nearly 30% over the last 30 years
AFQT scores explain racial wage gaps: Test accounts for 75% male gap, 100% female gap vs education levels. Skills deficit, not schooling, drives black-white earnings differential.

US business dynamism has declined significantly since 1985, with gross job creation falling 2.9% and gross job destruction by 1.5%. Young firms are driving this trend, with age composition change explaining 32% of job creation decline.

Bank balance sheet lending has declined from 60% of total private lending in 1970 to 35% in 2023. Private credit is increasingly intermediated through arms-length transactions such as securitization. @NBERpubs

From the pandemic to April 2025, foreign banks’ reserve holdings at the FRBNY continued to rise, even as domestic banks sharply reduced their holdings. Since July, Klein infers, $400B of the $500B reduction in reserves was attributable to foreign banks.
The CRFB team estimates that the Senate's reconciliation bill will result in a deficit of 7% of GDP next year. This estimate doesn't account for tariff revenue.

According to the General Social Survey, the share of Americans (18–64) reporting they had sex weekly dropped from 55% in 1990 to 37% in 2024. 24% of young adults 18–29 report not having sex within the last year.
.@DAcemogluMIT estimates that AI will have a modest 0.55% impact on total factor productivity over ten years, and may not have much effect on inequality.

There were 38,000 Chinese officials and businessmen in liuzhi - an extra-judicial form of detention - in 2024, almost a 50% increase from 2023. Another 200,000 individuals have been banned from "high consumption," such as staying at posh hotels.

A St. Louis Fed analysis finds that US manufacturing employment hit bottom just after the trough of the Great Recession. Half of the rise in the sector's employment btw 2014 and 2024 was in food manufacturing.
A Goldman analysis suggests restoring housing affordability to late 1990s levels will require construction of 3–4mm new units, equivalent to 2–2.6% of the current housing stock.

New York City’s elevated infrastructure costs relative to peers such as Paris are due to “stationary bandits” extracting wealth from the “tradable private sector.” Matt Yglesias argues for breaking NYC’s public sector unions.

A GS analysis argues the solar boom, driven by scale economies and the zero marginal cost of fuel, will persist despite falling subsidies. Prospects for additional growth hinge on price guarantees, cheap storage, and grid upgrades.
A new poverty measure shows a higher rate than conventional methods, indicating 8m more Americans are considered poor.
Higher-income families are increasingly taking on debt for undergraduate education, with 60% of high-income students borrowing in 2015-16, up from 30% in 1995-96, according to @JasonDelisle @AEI.

“Monthly core goods inflation in June 2025 was ~80bps above where it normally is at this time of year.” Robin Brooks notes that as pre-tariff inventories are depleted and the administration cracks down on transshipments, goods prices will rise.

In furnishings and recreation goods, two sectors that comprise 25% of core goods and are largely reliant on imports from China, “monthly inflation in June 2025 is running between 100 - 120 bps above where it would be normally at this time of year.”

The US corporate tax burden, currently at a combined rate of 25.8%, is slightly below the OECD average of 26%. Proposed increases to 28% or 26.5% would raise the US rate to 32.3% or 30.9%, positioning it among the highest in the OECD, highlighting potential competitiveness concerns.

Research by @OleAgersnap finds that the revenue-maximizing federal capital gains tax rate is btw 38-47%. A 5 percentage point increase in capital gains tax rates could generate $18-30bn in annual federal revenue.

Michael Cembalest argues a “Thucydides Cap” will limit Chinese stock market gains, "Geopolitics are more likely to negatively impact US investments in China in the years ahead than to surprise positively due to some kind of US-China detente."

In 2023:H2 the 10-year soared from 4% to 5%, then retreated to 3.9%. Averaging existing term structure models, Diercks and Asnani note that the 2,10 spread moves almost one-for-one with the term premium, and interpret the 2023 episode accordingly.

Btw 2014 and 2024, there was a "sustained erosion of conscientiousness" in young Americans (ages 16–39); they report "feeling increasingly easily distracted and careless, less tenacious and less likely to make and deliver on commitments."

A Bloomberg analysis finds that prices dropped on 51 of 67 products and services in China over the past two years. 34% of Chinese firms are unable to cover interest on their debt - a 25-year high - as China’s deflationary spiral worsens.

Apart from initial volatility in gold and pharma imports, US tariffs have yet to impact net trade flows. Soaring imports from Taiwan and SE Asia led to growth in total imports from Asia to the US in spite of reduced trade with China.

Efforts by advanced economies to offset demographic decline via immigration have been met with widespread public opposition. Slower growth associated with lower immigration likely means “ever greater demands on the purse of the native-born population.”
Income inequality in the US is often overstated due to exclusion of taxes & transfer payments. After accounting for these factors, the income gap narrows significantly. @PhilGramm @JohnEarly @WSJ.

Bank of America data show that while the bottom 1/3 of American households’ after-tax income grew faster than that of the top 2/3rds in 2023–2024, the top 1/3 has outpaced lower-income earners since the start of this year.

Non-government layoffs are not high, but business hiring is not far above its level during the 2008–2009 financial crisis. The number of labor market participants unemployed for more than 27 weeks rose from 1.45mm to 1.95mm between May and August 2025.

So far this year, China has installed 277 gigawatts of wind and solar capacity, 4x the scale of "utility-scale additions," via all power sources the US will bring online in 2025. Chinese firms now have a ~75% market share in clean energy manufacturing.

The incidence of tariffs so far is on US consumers, notes Matt Klein. “If foreigners were going to eat the cost, [pre-tariff] import prices should have fallen enough to offset the tariff. Excluding food and fuels, [they] are up about 1% so far in 2025.”

The White House is quietly exempting products that the US doesn’t domestically produce from reciprocal tariffs. The WSJ reports that the shift in tariffs reflects a “desire to hedge its bets should the court strike down its broad levies.”
In 2024, the United States exported about 30% of its domestic primary energy production. Nearly all of the exports were fossil fuels destined for other countries in North America, Europe, or Asia.

The rate of violent crime in urban areas increased 61% between 2019 and 2024, compared to increases of just 4% in suburban areas and 2% in rural areas over that period, according to the National Crime Victimization Survey.
Study: 1970s-present shows twin earnings trends - steady rise at top vs median, saw-tooth drops at bottom during recessions. Prime-age men (25-54) hit hardest in downturns, widening inequality gaps.

Brooks argues that the US’s “exorbitant privilege” - the ability to sell US debt to global markets at anomalously low yields - has faded; 10-year Treasury yields are now at a 20 bps premium relative to $ denominated yields in the rest of the G10.

Persistent trade deficits at current levels would push our net international investment position beyond levels sustained in any advanced economy. Stabilization will require an adjustment of at least 2% of GDP, implying real exchange depreciation of ~15–20%.

Jeremy Neufeld argues that DHS's H-1B proposal is “ill-equipped to rank workers” because its “F-1” criterion measures age and seniority rather than actual wages, and will penalize “genuinely high-wage, high-skill talent, especially students trained in the US.”
Rearmament in the West is boosting order books and backlogs at defense companies. Lockheed Martin reported an 11% increase in Q2 missile sales and revenue rose 8% in Raytheon's missile unit.

American adults now spend 4 hours a day watching digital video and < 3 hours watching traditional TV. YouTube, TikTok and Instagram now represent ~25% of US video screen time. AI text-to-video tools are facilitating content creation by new entrants.

AI productivity gains require policy reform for shared growth: Education/labor market/innovation investments crucial. Success depends on aligning workforce opportunities with technological advancement.

The sum of global exports and global imports relative to global GDP has been stable over the past decade. Robin Brooks argues that despite the ongoing trade wars, “we’re essentially in a holding pattern at peak globalization.”
US women are more likely to have children than a decade ago, despite delaying childbirth. Women with higher education are waiting longer but ultimately achieving higher fertility rates.

A loophole in the TCJA allows American corporations to book ~$350B in profits in Ireland, Luxembourg and Singapore. Large American pharmaceutical manufacturers effectively pay no corporate taxes to the US government.
Middle Class Is Shrinking....Because They're Moving Up. From 1967 to 2018, households earning over $100,000 tripled from 9.7% to 30.4% while middle-income households decreased from 53.8% to 41.7%.

Deceleration in wage growth suggests recent labor market weakness is being driven "primarily" by lower labor demand; this and reductions in corporate profits and consumer incomes due to tariffs could shift the FOMC's base case from 2 to 3 cuts this year.

Noting that over the past decade global CO2 emissions projected by the IEA have fallen by more than 40%, Bill Gates argues innovation will likely “give us the tools we need to meet the growing demand for energy without increasing carbon emissions.”
USG funded WW1 with 20.8% taxes, 74.6% debt, 7% money growth. WW2: 30.2% taxes, 46% debt, 10.1% money growth. Covid: 3.5% taxes, 67% debt, 18.5% money growth.

New product entries follow a cyclical pattern, with initial bursts of new entries followed by market shakeouts. Data shows the average duration of initial entry stages has decreased over time, from 23.1 years to 4.9 years.

Zero-sum thinking, in terms of political and policy views is strongly associated with lower levels of intergenerational upward mobility. @S_Stantcheva notes, “Younger generations today are much more zero-sum than older ones.”

Olivier Jeanne and Jeongwon Son find that the cumulative effect of news about US tariffs on China in 2018-19 appreciated the dollar by about 1% and depreciated the renminbi by 2% against a broad basket of currencies.

Joseph Wang argues the market is likely overestimating the pace of rate cuts, given that "core inflation appears to have stabilized at around 3%" and "the employment picture has not deteriorated enough for it to abandon its inflation concerns."
Mark Zandi finds Americans in the top 10% of the income distribution accounted for 49.2% of consumer spending in Q2, the highest level since 1989.
Top income shares have barely changed in last 20yrs, excluding >99.99% 12,000 households. Share of incomes above 99% ~ $372,000 in 2012, but <99.99% ~ $7.2mm in 2012.
The lag btw scientific research & clean energy patents has increased from 5 to 8 years since the 1980s, highlighting a growing dependency on underlying science.

Based on a Dept. of Commerce survey of 1.2mm US businesses, only 6.6% of firms, representing 12% of employees, plan to use AI by Fall 2024. In the Information sector, 21.5% of firms with 25% of employees plan to use AI. @JHaltiwanger_UM

Product-level data on prices and effective tariff rates show pass-through of tariffs to retail prices increasing gradually, reaching 20% after 6 months. As of August, CPI had risen 2.9%, compared to an estimated 2.2% in the absence of tariffs.

China comprises 17% of global GDP but 29% of manufacturing and 13% of consumption while the US is 26% of GDP, 16% of manufacturing, and 26% of consumption. @michaelxpettis favors capital controls over tariffs to correct these imbalances.

.@D_A_Irwin argues that exchange rate reform during the 1990s, including the % of developing countries on dual or multiple exchange rates, was a reaction to shortages of foreign currency and a rejection of the distortionary quotas used to manage them.
China shocks impacted US manufacturing most in late product cycle industries by 1990, with 0.25% higher unemployment rates in areas with low education & high wages.
Torsten Sløk notes that 41% of the S&P 500’s revenue comes from abroad.
US productivity gains btw 1995-2005 were largely attributed to ICT advancements, leading to a 17% annual productivity growth in its ICT-hardware industry.
US health insurance industry reported net earnings of $23.4bn in 2018, a significant increase from $16.1bn in 2017.

Danish data show that the probability of becoming either an R&D worker or a “transformative entrepreneur” who hires R&D workers and pursues innovation is highly correlated with IQ. Non-transformative entrepreneurship often reflects family background.

Estimating evolving expectations of lifetime resources over 40 years of Danish data, @r_landersoe finds that although 80% of male children have higher disposable income at ages 30-35 than their fathers, only 60% have higher lifetime income.
Investors keep “piling” into Treasuries. The 10-year yield has fallen ~50bps this year, to ~4%, by far the largest decline among the G-7 countries.
Republicans may pull the “Revenge Tax” provision from the reconciliation bill as the Treasury Department nears a deal with OECD partners over global minimum taxes on multinational corporations.

The Treasury Department announced a deal with G-7 allies that will exclude US companies from OECD Pillar 2 taxes in exchange for removing the Section 899 “revenge tax” proposal from President Donald Trump’s tax bill.

Stable bid-to-cover rates and the absence of auctions “systematically tailing” indicate strong demand for Treasuries, but rising debt servicing costs and term premia suggest “gradually higher long-term rates and steepening of the yield curve.”

Stein et al argue that in a repeat of the March 2020 crisis in which hedge funds rapidly unwound leveraged Treasury basis trades (long cash bonds, short futures), the Fed should undertake hedged interventions rather than outright purchases of Treasuries.

.@CarlShapiro finds that empirical evidence does not show a widespread decline in US competition and that “observed changes are likely to reflect competition in action.” For example, rising corporate profits % of GDP result from rising foreign earnings.

Btw 2017 and Q2 2025 reserve managers have gradually pulled out of the Dollar and shifted into other currencies. The beneficiaries - which do not include the Euro - have been the Australian Dollar, the Canadian Dollar, and the Chinese Yuan.

In 2022, the present value of Social Security was ~50% of the wealth of American families at the median of the wealth distribution, ~34% at the 75th percentile, and 20% at the 90th. The wealth shares of the top 1% and top 5% both rose by 4pp since 1989.
The rise in American geographic inequality is primarily driven by the concentration of affluence, with top income quantiles diverging significantly across states since the late 1970s.

The Trump administration is considering taking a 10% stake in Intel via converting ~$10.9B in grants committed under the US Chips and Science Act into an equity stake. The USG would be the company’s largest shareholder.

The Federal government is taking a 10% stake in Intel by converting $8.9B in grants previously awarded under the Chips act, but not yet paid, into equity. The government will be the company’s largest shareholder and will not hold a board seat.
The dollar is off >10% against the euro, pound, and Swiss franc since January. Paul Tudor Jones argues American fiscal expansion will lead to another 10% $ decline over the next 12 months.

In exchange for export licences to export H20 chips to China which had been previously banned by US export controls, Nvidia, as well as AMD, will turn 15% of their revenue from China sales over to the US government.

President Trump signed an executive order declaring the spinoff of TikTok's US operations to American investors for $14B compliant with current law. Congress may remain skeptical that the deal taking shape meets the 2024 law’s terms.
The US and Japan have reached a trade deal that will impose a 15% tariff on Japanese imports. The deal includes a pledge of $550B for Japanese investment in the US.

Illegal immigrants constitute ~ 4.4% of the overall American workforce according to a GS analysis, but make up 13% of construction workers, 16% of animal slaughtering and processing workers, and 17% of farm workers.

American consumption as a share of GDP at 81%, including government, is the highest in the G7, aside from the UK. The other advanced economies' consumption share of GDP is 5pp lower on average than that of the US.
Responding to the unveiling of new Chinese export controls, Donald Trump threatened to cancel his upcoming meeting with Xi and said he is considering a “massive increase” in US tariffs on China.

Due to stronger growth, the underlying real short-term interest rate in the US is ~ 1pp higher than in the euro area. US inflation is also ~1pp higher. Jesper Rangvid concludes the current FFR is appropriate.
Trump's fiscal policies resulted in $7.8tn in new spending over a decade, surpassing Obama & Bush. Spending was driven by pandemic relief, 2017 tax cuts & increased discretionary spending caps.

Bloomberg projects that the long-term real natural interest rate will rise to 2.8% by 2030, the highest since 2000. Demographics, debt, reduced Asian buying, and spending on defense, AI, and climate change may lead the 10-year nominal rate to exceed 6%.

Observers of the SCOTUS hearing on tariffs imposed under the 1977 IEEPA suggest that at least 6 of the 9 justices are likely to rule against the tariffs. Gorsuch argued Congress’s sole power to “reach into the pockets” of taxpayers is “just different.”

Tariffs have generated $152B through July, ~ 2x the revenue collected over the same period last year. Trump’s tariffs may persist through a change of government due to the scale of the revenue and the difficulty of offsetting it via new taxes.
TSMC will attempt to accelerate construction of its second and third Arizona plants to meet American demand; the plants will enable TSMC to manufacture ~30% of its most advanced chips in Arizona.

New National Assessment of Educational Progress results show the share of American high school seniors who scored basic or above on national tests fell to the lowest level on record: 68% in reading and 55% in math.

If US developers’ plans are realized, they will bring online a record 64 GW of new power in 2025, with solar accounting for 50%. That would surpass the previous record of 58 GW of new energy brought online in 2002, of which 98% was fueled by natural gas.

The U.S. economy faces challenges in achieving adequate growth, capacity utilization, and financial stability due to secular stagnation and hysteresis. @LHSummers suggests a need for new policy approaches to stimulate demand and restore economic potential.
Chinese capital outflows significantly impacted U.S. real estate btw 2010-2016, with $1bn in net money and deposit outflows from China correlating to a $0.7bn increase in inflows to the U.S.

Underlying inflation is running ~ 1–1.5pp above its pre-pandemic rate. @M_C_Klein notes, “With underlying inflation holding steady and the potential for tariffs to push things further, price risks seem to be skewed towards the upside."

Labor demand and employment remain strong; 80.7% of US residents aged 25–54 have a job - near the recent peak. Hiring, however, has slowed; unemployment for those <25 has risen enough to affect the aggregate unemployment rate.
US manufacturing market concentration remained stable btw 1992-2012 when accounting for foreign firms' sales.

Management of DoD's Replicator program, an effort to deploy low-cost autonomous weapons at scale in the western-Pacific, is being shifted to a new Defense Autonomous Warfare Group in an effort to accelerate the program.
US primary energy production hit a record high in 2024, while consumption remained under the 2007 peak, driving record net exports which rose 4% y/y.
During the pandemic era “Great Retirement Boom,” >2.4mm people retired in excess of trend, @mfariacastro finds. As of 2024, retirements had reverted to their prepandemic trend.

The US tax code has become more progressive since 1979, largely driven by tax credits for low-income individuals. Progressivity has more than doubled since 1986, according to @DavidSplinter in the National Tax Law Journal.

The White House is planning to cut tariffs on goods from Ecuador, Argentina, El Salvador and Guatemala that are not produced domestically, such as coffee and bananas, as well as tariffs on Argentinian beef.

Pew estimates the unauthorized immigrant population was 14mm in 2023, or 4.1% of the population. They also estimate that in January 2025, 53mm immigrants comprised a record 15.8% of the US population; there was a likely 1mm drop btw then and June.

Tariffs will not return highly labor-intensive production to the US, and thus will have little effect on inequality of market income. But, per the Budget Lab, “they’re part of a policy mix that will greatly increase inequality after taxes and transfers.”

Since 1973 median pay has risen 50% while average productivity rose 111%; @swinshi finds the divergence has been driven by “fanning out” in workers' productivity and slowing in the growth of men's wages as women entered the labor force.

Baker, et al found that a shift to universal child care led to a rise in aggression, anxiety and hyperactivity among Quebecer children. James Heckman, who found very high returns to a small, high quality pilot program, warns against low-cost imitations.

Focusing on 5 manufacturing industries for which physical measures of gross output are available, Weijian Shan finds that Chinese labor productivity (measured as physical units of output per worker) is 2 to 3 times that of the US in 4 of the 5 sectors.
Updated @USCBO projections forecast the 2024 federal budget deficit will be almost $2T or 7.0% of US GDP, up from 6.2% in 2023.

A closely watched auction of 30-year Treasuries saw stronger-than-expected demand on Thursday. The $22B sale drew a yield of 4.84%, down 8 bps. The group of primary dealers that underwrite US Treasury debt offerings were awarded only 11.4% of the sale.

Corporate bond trading has changed from “a relationship-based business to a more transaction-based [one],” reducing search costs in “normal times,” while replacing the broker dealers who held inventories needed to provide liquidity in times of stress.
Borrowing costs for investment grade firms in the US and Eurozone are .75 and .76pp above the benchmark government bond yields, respectively, the lowest levels since 1998 and 2018, respectively.

Yesterday’s 25bp cut leaves the Funds Rate at 4–4.25%. Goldman Sachs forecasts an additional two cuts in October and December 2025, followed by two cuts in 2026, leading to a terminal rate of 3.0–3.25%.

@LHSummers @LHSummers argues that achieving adequate growth, capacity utilization, and financial stability is increasingly challenging for the US and other industrial economies due to secular stagnation.

Net foreign inflows into US assets were near a record high in May. Robin Brooks argues that U.S. exceptionalism is “alive and well,” with the fall in the Dollar likely driven by temporary liquidity issues “at a time of heightened risk aversion.”
The US Government is in negotiations with Lithium Americas to take an equity stake in the mining company in exchange for an extension of a $2.3B DoE loan.
The US is taking a 10% stake in Canada’s Trilogy Metals in an effort to increase Alaskan and Canadian production of copper, cobalt, gallium and germanium.

.@KClausing notes that 350 US firms represent 70% of the tax base, and argues that international cooperation is required to maintain competitiveness of domestic firms while preventing profit-shifting to low-tax jurisdictions.

The cost of casualty insurance rose 8% in Q1 2025; costs have risen for 23 successive quarters. Carriers are considering withdrawing from the liability market due to "runaway jury verdicts" & increasing lawsuits driven by the litigation funding industry.
The median age of first-time homebuyers in the US has climbed to a record of 40, up from 33 in 2021.

In May, the first full month of the 10% universal tariff, revenue hit a record $24.2B, 14.5% of the mean monthly deficit over the last year. Tariff revenue is projected at $1.8T over the next decade, offsetting ~½ of the $3.4T deficit hike in the OBBBA.

An ECB analysis finds Euro Area affiliates of US multinationals account for >5% of EA value added and are responsible for ~ 30% of the EA 2024 goods surplus vis-a-vis the US. Overall, the EA-US current account was ~ at par in 2024.
Wealth tax could enhance risk-seeking equity by reallocating capital to higher productivity activities, boosting average lifetime utility by 7.5% in consumption-equivalent terms.

Analyzing new survey evidence from Japan, Masayuki Morikawa finds that “more-educated workers are more likely to use AI, suggesting that AI and education are complementary.” Workers who use AI believe it has raised their productivity by 20% on average.

IMF data show China accounts for > 50% of the increase in the global economy’s government debt-to-GDP ratio since 2008 - a result, Pettis argues, of “the buildup of extensive unrecognized losses across China’s economy, which cannot be ignored forever.”
An MIT analysis finds that of the $30-40B in enterprise investment into GenAI, "95% of organizations are getting zero return."
VC impact quantified: +1 std-dev funding drives +1.3% employment, +1.9% sales growth. VC-backed firms show superior innovation metrics: higher patent share, elevated R&D/sales ratios.

Krugman blames anomalously low consumer sentiment partly on post-traumatic stress from the Covid inflation. “Even when wages rise faster than prices, people believe that they earned their wage increases, only to have their gains taken away by inflation.”

“Historical Context Matters.” Both Biden’s term and Reagan’s 1st term saw a ~20% rise in the price level, but only Biden’s saw a sharp drop in sentiment. Consumers had gotten used to inflation in the 1970s, while the Covid inflation came as a shock.
The US is imposing a 20% tariff on imports from Vietnam and a 40% rate on those “transshipped” through the country in an effort to reduce American trade with China.

Alexandra Tabova and Francis Warnock find that two of three major purchasers of Treasuries, US private purchasers and foreign private purchasers, have elastic demand curves, implying that rates will tend to go higher as Treasury issuance increases.

New @nberpubs finds that Medicaid expansion between 1994 and 2005 had no impact on mortality rates: "we find no evidence that Medicaid expansions affect any of the outcomes in any of the treated states or all of them combined."

Value-added/full-time employee in the US construction sector was ~40% lower in 2020 than in 1970; had construction productivity grown at 1% a year, aggregate US labor productivity would have been 10% higher.  @Austan_Goolsbee @ChadSyverson @nberpubs

A @nberpubs analysis finds workers who are working from home in the US save an average of 55 minutes with 39% of those time savings being devoted to a primary or secondary jobs and 33% for leisure activities.  @I_Am_NickBloom
.@DrDaronAcemoglu finds that negative externalities and excessive focus on high-margin technologies can distort the path of innovation and reduce welfare gains by 10-50%. @nberpubs

Evidence from Finland suggests that expansion of a home care allowance decreases maternal employment in both the short and long term and results in lower educational attainment and increased youth crime for impacted children. @nberpubs

.@akorinek reports on how large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT could increase productivity in economics research by focusing human effort on posing questions and providing feedback and editing of drafts from LLMs.

A new @NBERpubs paper shows that newer firms have more earnings dispersion than older firms, and that this pattern accounts for a large fraction of the aggregate rise in between-firm earnings inequality. @WallskogMelanie

15% of American workers are independent contractors, according to a Gallup survey that was carefully constructed to avoid data problems that had previously plagued the space. @kgahome @BHershbein @bethtruesdale
Over 10% of job listings in the Anglosphere countries now allow for remote work for at least one day a week. @I_Am_NickBloom @StephenEKHansen @pj_lambert @raffasadun @Bledi_Taska

Robert Hall argues that a substantial rise in the volatility of costs can free the prices of a significant fraction of goods and services prices from the grip of New Keynesian "zone of inaction.” @NBERpubs

A review of shareholder letters from 1955 and 2020 finds that corporations “pick and choose the stakeholders they want to focus attention on, while emphasizing long-term shareholder value, especially in how they compensate.” @zingales
.@nomadj1s and @ernietedeschi present evidence showing that the expansion of the child tax credit in 2021 didn't significantly reduce labor supply in the short term.
Between 1992 and 2017 the shift from manufacturing to the service sector reduced local employment concentration, even as national concentration rose. @davidautor @johnvanreenen

A new @NBERpubs paper shows that parents' comparative skill advantage in math (vs. language) is significantly linked to the comparative skill advantage of their children. @EricHanushek @SimonWiederhold

Using evidence from two large retailers @RDMetcalfe @ASollaci @ChadSyverson find that individual managers, outside of firm-wide management practices, explain 25-35% of variance in store level productivity.

A @NBERpubs study presents evidence on the market impact of LLMs. Firms with top quintile exposure to AI outperformed firms with lowest quintile exposure to AI by over 9% from Dec 1 to Mar 31. @andrea_eisfeldt @gregorschub @rainozhang

A review of relevant research suggests increased availability of immigrant household workers has had large positive effects on the labor supply of highly educated female workers and on the gender wage gap.  @cortespatico

.@JoshuaLKrieger @Danielle__Li @DimitrisPapan20 examine R+D investment in drug development and find that research into novel therapies often leads to profitable opportunities in successor therapies that are closely related.

Detailed analysis by @Tfpiasecki shows that American manufacturing firms have not fully substituted foreign for domestic production, but rather supplement their domestic efforts with foreign production.

.@NielsGormsen shows that the average firm reduces its discount rate by only .3% in response to a 1% decline in perceived cost of capital. The implication is a lower level of capital spending relative to what the decline in cost of capital would imply.

.@KarstenMueIIer and @EmilVerner find that credit growth to non-tradable industries like real estate is predictive of a boom-bust output pattern and financial fragility, while credit to the tradable sector is associated with productivity growth.
Evidence from CA shows that between 2002-2016 Asian immigration is associated with a decline in white student enrollment in public schools. @leah_boustan
New @NBERpubs paper finds that there is no empirical evidence that government spending related to the space race contributed to excess economic growth on the national level.

Improvement in the US debt-GDP ratio from 1946-1974 was driven primarily by primary government surpluses and distortions of real interest rates from surprise inflation and from pegged nominal rates, not overall economic growth. @AcalinJulien
Expected earnings for S&P 500 firms “fully explain observed stock market fluctuations from 1980-2022,” and help explain macroeconomic boom-bust cycles @NBERpubs
Large Language Models (LLM) will likely accelerate knowledge creation by making science research and data more transparent and rigorous. @Econ_4_Everyone @brian_jabarian
Zero-sum thinking in terms of political and policy views is strongly associated with lower levels of intergenerational upward mobility. @S_Stantcheva @DrNathanNunn
Among 400,000 people who graduated from Ivy League schools between 1970 and 2021, athletes earned 3.4% more than non-athletes over the course of their careers. @NateeA1

A new @nberpubs analysis documents that the natural interest rate moves in a very wide range of 400-500 basis points across advanced economies.  There is a strong global factor in r*, such that natural rates tend to move together across countries.
Robert Hall and @MariannaKudlyak argue the natural rate of unemployment has fallen in the aftermath of the financial crisis to 3.5%.

Analysis by Loukas Karabarbounis finds that labor’s share of US national income declined 5pp btw 1929-2022, and labor’s share globally has declined 6pp since 1980. He proposes capital-augmenting technology as the most likely driver of these declines.

Pappada and @krogoff argue the size of the “off the books”  economy exhibits counter-cyclical variation over time, and that it represents nearly 30% of GDP in Southern Europe vs. World Bank estimates of 20%.
The decline in internal migration in the US has been driven by increasing housing prices; potential wage gains from migration are being offset by housing-related factors.

.@davidautor argues that AI can help rebuild middle-class jobs by democratizing higher-stakes decision-making tasks to lower and middle-skilled workers that had previously been the providence of elite experts.

A recent @NBERpubs paper confirms that global poverty and inequality declined dramatically between 1980 and 2019 and that “within-country inequality is falling on average, and has been largely constant since the 1990s” @XSalaimartin

Calomiris and Jaremski review ten famous financial crises from ancient Rome through the present and find four common factors: politically motivated subsidies, changes in investor preferences towards risk, unsophisticated investors, and fraud.

.@andy_garin et al. show that men born before WWII in counties chosen for large wartime plant construction earned 2.5% more per year in adulthood relative to those born in comparable regions, with benefits mainly to children born to low-income parents.

Using data from tax filers and W-2 recipients from 1998–2019, @AbigailWozniak, @john_voorheis, and @kevinrinz find that earnings for both Black men and Black women fell behind earnings for White men following the Great Recession.

Change in their relative earnings accounted for 44% of the growth in labor force exits among non-college men between 1980-2019, suggesting a decline in social status is a likely factor driving the decline in prime-age labor force participation. @BostonFed
Dependence on large buyers lowers suppliers’ wages & accounts for 10% of wage stagnation in nonfinancial firms since the 1970s.

“Many countries now have vast ‘contingent liabilities’ - off-balance-sheet commitments that nonetheless represent an enormous potential outlay.” The U.S. government “is on the hook for contingent liabilities worth more than 5X the country’s GDP.”

The PRC’s “China 2025” industrial policy, though far from achieving self-sufficiency, has moved target firms closer to the technological frontier. Btw 2015 and 2020, China gained a 4pp share of global patents in robotics and electric vehicles.
Slower economic growth, not rising inequality, is the primary factor behind declining absolute mobility, according to Scott Winship's analysis of Chetty's data.

.@AEI’s @swinshi revisits Raj Chetty’s data and argues that contrary to Chetty’s findings, slower economic growth has been a much more important driver of the reduction of absolute mobility than the rise in inequality.

Autor and Hanson warn the US faces a second "China Shock" that tariffs are ill-equipped to counter. According to an Australian analysis, btw 2003 and 2007, the US led China in 60 of 64 cutting-edge sectors; by 2023, China led the US in 57 of the 64.
Americans, ages 18–24, spend more than three hours a day on social media; nearly an hour of it on TikTok. More than 116mm Americans use TikTok monthly.
Academically advanced youth show an average 9-point gain in ACT Composite scores from 7th to 11/12th grade, with growth influenced by demographic & socioeconomic factors.

Belgian data suggest that in the 5 years following “episodic engagement” with a management consultancy, firms see a 3.6% rise in labor productivity, associated with modest reductions in labor and capital input and no increase in profitability.
Analysis by @WilliamSpriggs in The Review Of Black Political Economic shows AFQT scores are racially biased, explaining only 5% of the male black-white wage gap when adjusted for bias.

Research by @NicholasBloom finds management practices account for 40% of variation across plants within same firm, highlighting significant intra-firm differences. This variation is comparable to R&D & twice that of IT on productivity spread.
The bottom 10% of firms destroy as much value as the top 10% create.

White women’s graduation rate rose 10pp more than white men’s btw the 1960 and 1980 cohorts. Returns to college, which rose twice as fast for women as men, account for 50%, and the “knock-on effect” of mothers’ rising education accounts for another 25%.

The decline in the natural rate of interest (r*) in the U.S. is primarily driven by rising income inequality rather than demographic shifts. Since the 1980s, the top 10% of earners have increased their share of national income by 10-15pp.
GPU rental rates at the hyperscalers are relatively stable, while overall per-hour rates for Nvidia’s H200 and H100 chips are down 29% and 22%, respectively, year to date.
Slowdown in knowledge diffusion accounts for 70% of declining US business dynamism, according to @SinaTAtes of the @nberpub.

Americans’ exposure to the stock market, at 30% of household net worth, exceeds the dotcom era’s 26%. The Economist’s Bird and Williams warn, “Should Digital God fail to arrive, the fall will be brutal."

The 10-year Treasury yield, relative to the trade-weighted, exchange rate-adjusted yield on 10-year governments in other advanced economies, rose over the last decade but has fallen in recent months, suggesting “many other fiscal train wrecks out there.”

Contrary to the usual presumption that increases in tariffs are stagflationary, US evidence going back to 1870 suggests that tariffs raise unemployment but lower inflation, consistent with the view that tariffs are contractionary aggregate demand shocks.

Andrew Biggs notes that the maximum Social Security payout for a high-income couple is almost $100,000 annually, 2 to 4 times higher in dollar terms than the payouts for their peers in other Anglosphere countries.

Unemployment for recent American college graduates is up 1.3pp since 2022. Unemployment for the generally younger group of non-college workers, measured at labor market entrance rather than at ages 22-27, has seen a 2.4pp rise.

China's household consumption plummeted from 53% of GDP in 1983 to 39% today (compared to ~70% for the US), driven by a sharp decline in household sizes and incomes as “decades of fertility-control policies have left China with relatively few children.”
According to a WSJ analysis, there were 1,135 billionaires in the US in 2024, worth a collective $5.7T. ~⅓ of American billionaires inherited much or all of their wealth.

Gold’s spot price has risen ~59% since the start of the year. Since Powell’s Jackson speech, gold has risen ~25% while the dollar has remained stable against G10 currencies in a broad debasement of advanced economies’ currencies relative to gold.

Noting that the end of the US government shutdown “has seen a resumption of the precious metals rally” with “gold and silver back to near their October highs,” Brooks concludes that “appetite for safe havens is much stronger than I would have thought.”
